PETITION.TITLE: Five-Dollar Note
PETITION.PARA: To the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

There is widespread concern in the Australian community about the proposal by the Reserve Bank of Australia to produce a new plastic $5 note that will feature the Queen, and that the present $5 note featuring Caroline Chisholm will be removed from circulation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, urge the Reserve Bank to adopt a design for the new note that will promote and identify the unique character of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: South Africa: Political Prisoners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

That they are committed to the elimination of the abominable and inhuman system of apartheid in South Africa, as practised by the minority Government of that country, consistent with the promotion of human rights and civil liberties.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

Urge the Federal Government to formally request the South African Government to immediately cease the practice of apartheid, by repealing all laws and regulations relating thereto, and by the release of any political prisoners detained by virtue of such laws, and by any other means consistent with the human rights and civil liberties of all its people.

PETITION.TITLE: Port Hedland/Marble Bar Road
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
* The Port Hedland/Marble Bar road is in terrible condition;
* As far back as the early 1950s the people of Marble Bar were promised an all weather road;
* The poor state of the gravel road is deterring tourists from seeing the many attractions in the Marble Bar area and causing untold damage to the town's economy.
Your petitioners respectfully request that the Senate urge the Government to ensure that funds are made available for the essential upgrading of this important road.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call on Senator Crane, I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech in this chamber. Therefore, I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. On this, the occasion of my first speech to the Senate, I feel very proud and privileged to be elected as a senator for Western Australia. It is a great honour to be part of a team of six Liberal senators representing Australia's largest State. I sincerely thank the people of Western Australia and will endeavour to represent them to the best of my ability.

SPEECH.PARA: At this point, I must also thank the many people who supported me during the election campaign. I would particularly like to acknowledge Jim Sampson, who finally convinced me that I should nominate. I thank the Clerk of the Senate, Harry Evans, and his team of people for their enormous amount of help. I found the orientation seminars extremely useful. As well, I thank Chris Pelzer and the staff in the Department of Administrative Services in Western Australia; our Whip, Senator Reid; and honourable senators for their help and understanding. I congratulate the President, in his absence, on his election.

I wish to define what I see as the role of government. That is to establish policy and provide the infrastructure that is required to facilitate the running and operations of the nation; in particular to create an environment in which individuals can maximise their opportunity. It is not to be involved in business ventures and doing those things which business can perform. It is essential that competition be the cornerstone of our system, so that we can become internationally competitive.

In my time in the Senate I will concentrate upon the issues which led to my decision to stand for election. That decision was not an easy one. As a farmer-businessman, I find that my life is busy. This has led me to a heavy involvement with the Western Australian Farmers Federation and the National Farmers Federation. From 1973 to 1988, I was an elected member of the executive of the Western Australian Farmers Federation. From 1978 to 1988, I was on the National Farmers Federation council and/or executive. During this time I served as President at the State level and Senior Vice-President at the Federal level.

My particular interests are in industrial matters, economic management, trade and conservation. In addition, I have served as a director and chairman on a number of boards. I am particularly aware of the difficulties that face us today, not just those that face farmers but of the many that confront an employee, employer, small business and larger corporations. To be more precise, I am alarmed and appalled at the growth in bankruptcies, the imbalance in our trading figures and the ceaseless spiral in interest rates and inflation.

I particularly wish to bring to attention Australia's net debt situation in the Association of South East Asian Nations countries. It is a situation that we can hardly be proud of. Unless addressed, it means that the next generation of Australians, for the first time since Federation, will be handed a lower standard of living. The economy of this country is grinding to a halt. This is the main reason for my decision to seek office as a senator-to influence the direction that the Australian economy must take to recover. Unless we fix the economy, stabilise our debt, reform our taxation and industrial systems and take a much more responsible position on fiscal management, business will not have the resources required to address, in the practical sense, the conservation and environmental requirements of our resource based industries; nor will governments be able to tackle the problems we have with those who are disadvantaged, for whatever the reason; nor will we be able to overcome the problems in our medical institutions.

The next few years are going to be crucial if Australia is not to slide irreversibly into economic oblivion and disaster. Australia cannot be proud of the fact that our credit rating has been cut. Of concern is a continually over-valued Australian dollar. This has been brought about by excessive use of high interest rates with the emphasis on monetary policy and not enough on fiscal policy at Federal, State and local government levels. This overvalued dollar has meant that our export industries have not been able to maximise our export returns. A much tighter fiscal policy with less reliance on monetary policy, and hence a lower dollar, would have allowed our exporters to compete internationally and would have taken pressure off our domestic manufacturing industries against the flood of imports coming into this country.

Excessive taxation and excises, high interest rates, government red tape and an ever increasing national debt are strangling us all. Throughout Australia there would not be a single person who has not felt the effects of the downturn in our economy. This year, 1990, is the start of a new decade. It is our opportunity to stop the ever increasing fall in living standards. The average family is struggling to pay for their home. In fact, the average Western Australian family buying their home is almost $100 a week worse off than they were in 1983. Record interest rates, spiralling inflation and increased housing costs have made the great Australian dream of owning one's own home a nightmare. Home buying families can spend up to a third of their weekly earnings on mortgage repayments, another third on tax, leaving one-third to clothe, feed and educate the family.

Since 1983 Australia's economic ranking in the world has declined alarmingly. Our foreign debt has increased from $23 billion in March 1983 to a record $124 billion in July of this year. That represents a debt in excess of $7,000 for every man, woman and child-that is, three times that of Argentina and 10 times that of the Philippines. If those countries are considered Third World countries, it poses the question: where do we stand?

Our current account deficit has reached a new record high-$21.2 billion; a blow-out of 19 per cent or $2.7 billion above the Budget forecast. The prediction for 1991 of $18 billion is, I believe, an underestimate. In the Asian region, we are at the bottom of the economic heap. A recent survey by a business international global consultancy group showed that Australia's debt stands at $US104 billion. The next worst country in Asia is India with $US59 billion.

Similarly, our current account deficit is much higher than those of other countries in the Asian region. At present it is running at $US15.2 billion, significantly more than India's, which is once again the second worst off country at $US3.7 billion, and is in a completely different class to Japan's surplus of $US53 billion. The study forecast a gross domestic product growth of 1.5 per cent in 1990 for Australia, the lowest of the 14 countries and just one-sixth of the leader, Thailand, at 9 per cent. It is not only in the Asian region where Australia has fallen behind. Figures released recently by Consensus Economics in Great Britain put Australia second last amongst the top 13 industrial countries in the economic stakes. This is a continuing decline from eleventh to twelfth spot on world rankings. Clearly, this slide has to be arrested. Australia needs to make economic decisions that will have long term beneficial effects on our economy.

The key to our economic recovery is a taxation system that provides incentive to those who invest and those who are prepared to work harder; an industrial system that allows for enterprise agreements on the ground, one which will encourage them to expand business and join to be more efficient producers. In our current industrial process through the centralised wage-fixing system mediocrity is rewarded, when in fact it is those who perform who should get the rewards.

To put Australia back on the road to economic recovery we need to take the imposts off the backs of our efficient industries, effectively reform the waterfront and transport industries, take steps to make our manufacturing industries efficient, and put a stop to the many ridiculous work practices which strangle our performance. For example, in Asian ports they move more than 60 containers an hour; in Europe, approximately 35; in Australia, on a good day, they move 20. In Singapore a ship can be turned around in less than 24 hours. The same ship in Sydney can take up to 14 days. In Australia it costs approximately $220 for a bale of wool to be stored for a year. Overseas it costs approximately $120 per bale. I cannot accept that our costs have to be double those of other countries.

To become internationally competitive it is essential also that we address immediately the problems of high levels of protection in a number of our industries, particularly textile, clothing and footwear and the motor car industry. Protection has a very damaging effect on our export industries and import competing industries. This is highlighted in the Garnaut report. But in particular I want to bring to the attention of the Senate the impact that protection has on families, especially low income families. The average cost per family of protection in the textile industry is in excess of $400 per annum. The cost of protection for each pair of shoes a family buys is in the order of $30 a pair. Recently when I was in Thailand I bought six pairs of leather shoes for a total cost of $96. In Australia similar shoes would have cost in excess of $100 a pair.

The featherbedding that has developed in many of our industries in the past 40 to 50 years has run its course. It is not compatible to have a deregulated financial system and yet continue with a regulated industrial system, protection for inefficient industries, a regulated transport system and a regulated waterfront. Australia must learn to compete across the full spectrum of industries. The fact is that if one interferes with the realities of the marketplace, that is, supply and demand, in the end the bubble will burst. In our case the bubble is our spiralling national debt and our current account deficit. Without effective competition in the marketplace across the full spectrum, our economic slide will continue.

One of the most serious indications of the decline in our economy is evident in small business. It is now a daily occurrence for small businessmen to be driven into giving up the fight, closing their doors and becoming just another statistic. Bankruptcies have risen by 11 per cent since 1985, forcing an average of six businesses a day to admit defeat. The Australian public has been told repeatedly that government policy on interest rates will benefit them in the long run, with a lower deficit and better balance of trade. That has not happened. The deficit is a ball and chain around the necks of every Australian.

As I said previously, the current account deficit stands at $21.2 billion, of which 75 per cent is interest repayments to service Australia's net foreign debt of $124 billion. So $3 out of every $4 is paid on interest repayments. Consequently, our current account deficit is ballooning. These figures clearly show that Australia is caught in a debt trap with no visible means of escape. I will forgive honourable senators if they think that this speech is an economic lecture rather than a maiden speech but, as I said at the outset, certain issues led to my decision to stand for Parliament. I cannot, in all honesty, stand idly by and not appeal to all levels of government to accept that hard decisions have to be made that will, in effect, address our debt problems and rejuvenate our economy.

It does not matter from what side of the political spectrum one comes, the impact, unless addressed, will be that Australia will not be effective with conservation, environmental or social policy. Outside politics it sometimes seems that the politicians do not understand what it is like to have lost a job, to battle with a home or business mortgage, to have a teenage son or daughter trying to find a job, or to have a farm or business disappear because of a forced sale. Having been recently elected to this place, being a farmer/businessman, and having been a shearer for 17 years in order to establish that business, I have a clear understanding of the economic pressures that are facing Australians today and I intend to highlight to all honourable senators, as often as is necessary, those problems and uncertainties.

In order to effectively address our economic problems, it is essential that we capitalise more effectively on our trading opportunities. As I have already stated, this means that our domestic manufacturing industries must be competitive. Talking of value-adding to our raw materials is pie in the sky unless we are internationally competitive. In order to maximise the performance of our producers in the trade arena, we must have economic and industrial systems that are compatible with those of our competitors. We must continue, through the Cairns group, to keep pressure on those countries, particularly the United States and Europe, to reduce the high levels of support which the taxpayers of those countries provide for their respective industries.

We must also pursue relentlessly the Asian opportunity. In Asia an economy the size of Japan's is growing every 18 months. It is predicted that this will continue for at least 30 years. It is in this area that Australia's trading future lies. To take advantage of it we must out-compete other countries around the world. It is only through maximising these opportunities that we can expand our net export performance in order, firstly, to stabilise our debt and then to start reducing it. In this effort there can be no complacency, nor can there be any tolerance of inefficient performance or work practices. We must maximise the comparative advantage we enjoy over many other countries and we must develop trading agreements which will, in fact, allow us to lower the cost of living in Australia and hence begin to improve our living standards.

There are many other issues on which I would like to talk in detail, but there is not time. These include the issue of foreign policy, and I support very strongly the stance taken by the Federal Government in conjunction with other countries of the United Nations in regard to the situation in Iraq. It is essential that when a country plays the big bully the rest of the world effectively says `no'. It is also important that the cost of applying sanctions be borne by the total community and not by a few industries or individuals. Steps must be taken to ensure that those affected by the sanctions imposed on Iraq are effectively compensated and the additional costs, because of the decision made, alleviated. In this case it is particularly important to our wheat industry because it has provided 96 per cent of our total exports to Iraq.

Our foreign aid policy needs to be closely scrutinised to make sure that those countries we are targeting to assist are, in fact, receiving the benefits. Our social welfare programs need to be targeted so that those who are genuinely disadvantaged or unable to help themselves can get the assistance. I believe that those people who can afford to pay or help themselves should pay their own way and not be a drain on the public purse.

We have a need to seriously address whether the regime of unemployment benefits that has developed over the years is in fact self-defeating, because I believe we now have a percentage of the community who think that society owes them a living, when the reverse is the case. I believe that our current health care program is in grave danger of collapsing. The waiting time at public hospitals is quite frightening. The emphasis has to be switched back to private health cover.

Assistance to Aboriginal people must be based on allowing them to develop commercial independence as individuals. Without this they will not regain their dignity or their cultural identity and return to being the proud people they were many years ago. Our immigration policy must be based on what is best for Australia. Race, creed or colour has no place in the process.

I have no regard for those who choose to operate above and beyond the law to achieve their ends. In effect, this is holding the country to ransom. I was involved in a number of precedent-setting cases in the industrial arena whilst I was Chairman of the National Farmers Federation industrial committee. I place on public record that this also included successful legal actions against businesses and governments because they were operating outside the law. To adopt any other position is, in effect, endorsing anarchy. I do not care whether it is an individual, a union, an employer organisation, a business, a government, or the judiciary-a person or body that breaks the law should be made accountable through our legal systems. There are many other issues that I could raise, but I believe what I have said will outline, without a shadow of doubt, where I stand in principle.

I wish to end my first speech on the issue of conservation, the protection of the environment and sustainable industry development. It is important that this matter be dealt with in a practical, constructive manner and not in some romantic way which allows policy to be developed by people who scream from the treetops yet have little understanding of the dynamics that make up a society and allow a profitable economy. Without a thriving, profitable economy which maximises employment opportunities, I do not believe that the conservation environmental issues will be effectively addressed. Industry will be forced into a survivalist strategy rather than being able to develop a long term sustainable position.

It is particularly important that the Landcare program, which has been developed throughout Australia, be resourced in a manner which allows it, in conjunction with land users, to protect and sustain our basic resource-the soil. I point out to the Senate that this program was started by amendments to the Soil Conservation Act in Western Australia in 1982.

I am very proud to state that the decision to amend the Soil Conservation Act in Western Australia was taken after a meeting between me, in my capacity as land use spokesman for the Western Australian Farmers Federation, and the Hon. Dick Old who was the coalition Minister for Agriculture in Western Australia at the time. In saying this, I am not claiming that we alone were responsible for the push at the time to have an Act which facilitated a progressive Landcare program. That decision which, in essence, set up the structure of soil conservation and district committees is now the Landcare model that is being developed throughout Australia.

It is worth noting that by the end of this year more than 85 per cent of agricultural and pastoral areas in Western Australia will have soil conservation districts operating. An important feature of this program is that it is industry driven by the land users themselves with the total backing of the Division of Resource Management, which is an arm of the Western Australian Department of Agriculture.

Western Australia is very fortunate to have a man of the calibre of Dr Graham Robertson, who heads up this division. I must emphasise that, as this program develops, it is essential that it stay under the auspices of the Department of Agriculture and the responsible Minister.

Western Australian farmers planted more than 12 million trees last year and put in many kilometres of contour lines, interceptor drains and drainage systems. It is estimated that some 20 million trees will be planted on farms this year. The emphasis must be on covering the full spectrum of wind and water erosion and salinity control. In other States, as I understand it, the program is developing along similar lines.

I have a fundamental concern that the manpower resources required of researchers and scientists are not sufficient to meet the demand for essential research and extension that will be required to maximise the results of this program. It is, therefore, my intention to move, in the very near future, for an inquiry to conduct a thorough study of the resource requirements-both private and government-to maximise the benefits of this program.

A second major initiative in Western Australia is the integration of commercial trees into farming practice. This will have significant environmental benefits- particularly with the lowering of the water table, which will reduce salinity-and will also help to stabilise farm incomes.

In 1987, following extensive community participation, a timber strategy and forest management plan was adopted. I wish to acknowledge Dr Syd Shea, the Executive Director of the Department of Conservation and Land Management in Western Australia, who was the driving force behind this plan.

It is worth noting that in recent years in Western Australia over 50 million trees have been planted. Western Australia has increased its forest conservation estate by 340 per cent; timber royalties have increased by up to 400 per cent; and woodchip royalties have increased by 500 per cent. In the southern forest the cut-over area has been reduced by 40 per cent and there has been an increase of 500 per cent in the southern conservation estate. This demonstrates that we can have a sustainable timber industry and satisfy the environmental requirements by stabilising and increasing the forest conservation estate.

In view of the concerns of the people who have been parked in trucks around this place this week, if similar timber strategy and forest management plans could be developed in other States, their aspirations, and the aspirations of the opposing forces, could well both be satisfied.

I wish to thank honourable senators for the courtesy they have given me in delivering my maiden speech. I emphasise that the challenge we have before us is to make those hard decisions that are required to stabilise our debt and then to start reducing it.

We must maximise our export performance-which needs to be increased by 4 per cent net per annum during the 1990s-so we can stabilise our debt situation, and allow us to put Australia on the road to regain our position as an economic performer when measured against other countries in the world. It is then, and only then, that as a nation we will be able to tackle our other policy areas effectively. This will not be easy, but if we are not prepared to tackle it we will be negligent, not only towards our forefathers, who were the pioneers of this country, but also towards our children, because we would have passed to them decisions that we did not have the courage to make ourselves.
Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In assessing the Hawke Government's eighth Budget one must forcibly remind oneself that economic activity should not be an end in itself but that it should be, indeed, the means to achieve people's aspirations. This Budget, however, carefully avoids charting a positive direction. It confirms once again the ideological commitment of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to leave all decisions to the marketplace which takes no account of social and environmental values, or the long term consequences of ignoring them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats believe that, as a community, we must integrate social, environmental and economic objectives and, further, that the community is entitled to expect that the government of the day will intervene to achieve such integrated objectives. Instead, the Treasurer has continued once again his ideological commitment to deregulation. There is no direction, let alone a vision for the future.

This abdication of the responsibility to govern on behalf of the people of Australia is, unfortunately, shared by the coalition parties. It is little wonder that Dr Hewson's response to the Budget was largely devoid of any substantive critique on specific revenue and expenditure items. In fact, it is no wonder that Dr Hewson has refused at least two media invitations to discuss the Australian Labor Party's privatisation program. He would have had to congratulate Mr Keating for implementing the policies of the New Right. The truth is that the Opposition agrees with the Government and supports the push to sacrifice the public benefit on the altar of private greed.

The truth is that the coalition parties agree with the Government's Budget and that the Democrats are now the only real opposition and the only party to offer a genuine alternative to the Government's sell-out.

This non-Budget contains real spending increases of 0.6 per cent, and real revenue is budgeted to rise by 0.4 per cent, indicating a slight reduction in the planned surplus as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) compared with last year and, superficially, `a steady as she goes' approach. But some of the increased expenditure, particularly in social security, is due to the country's declining economic performance.

It is likely to get worse. The recent jump in unemployment by a further 43,000 indicates that the Government has underestimated the harvest its high interest rate policy is delivering. The social result of this strategy does not seem to have entered the equation.

The Government's housing portfolio Budget allocation has been cut by over 10 per cent in real terms, largely due to the axing of the first home owners scheme. Yet defence spending is forecast to be maintained in real terms. Our involvement in the Persian Gulf will no doubt blow out this particular estimate even further. So what sorts of priorities does this Government have? The Democrats' alternative budget details a real boost of 20 per cent to public housing which can be more than offset by economies of some $800m in the Defence portfolio.

Foreign aid is to remain at the scandalously low level of 0.3 per cent of GDP, well short of the United Nations target figure of 0.7 per cent of GDP. This is a national disgrace and shows that Australia is years behind the rest of the world in its strategic defence thinking. It is also a matter which the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) is now prepared to acknowledge is indeed a national shame.

Where is the increase in this Budget in research into alternative energy sources which the current oil crisis demands? Instead, the Government grants concessions to the petroleum resource rent tax (RRT) to continue our dependence on fossil fuels.

These examples are indicative of the thrust of Government policy: the public sector must be squeezed irrespective of the needs of the community, the needs of forward thinking or the aspirations of its citizens. We are harvesting the results of this inaction in poor public transport, inadequate environmental policies, perpetuation of poverty, inadequate health and education facilities, and a poorly regulated financial system which enriches the fast, smart operators at the expense of pensioners and low income earners, who lose their life savings.

The Commonwealth Government does have the duty to identify and rectify problems as they confront the Australian community. It is simply not good enough to draw an arbitrary line beyond which public spending cannot go and then arrange priorities to fit within that self-imposed straightjacket, no matter what is neglected. But this does not mean that fiscal policy should be loosened-far from it. Our alternative budget proposals do identify over $4 billion worth of badly needed expenditure items. However, that is only one side of the coin. It is the revenue side which the Treasurer should bolster, and the Australian Democrats will be pleased to assist the Government in this area.

High income earners should face more sharply progressive income taxation rates. All tax avoidance rorts should be crushed once and for all, and some form of wealth taxation should be introduced. We have shown that the extra revenue could and should be raised. More than $7 billion is identified in our alternative proposals which, coupled with our increased spending proposals, would deliver a further $3 billion surplus, or one per cent of GDP, which could be used to bring down interest rates and to achieve an exchange rate which enables our export industries to genuinely compete on the international market.

This is crucial to a fair economic strategy. The Australian Democrats believe that the burden of national economic development should be related to the capacity to pay; it should not rest on the indiscriminate basis of whether somebody is borrowing funds to buy a house or develop a small business.

We are an extremely low taxed country by international standards. Disregarding Turkey, we rank second lowest in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in terms of taxation as a percentage of GDP. The only country below us is the United States of America, and it must be remembered that the United States has a huge Federal Government fiscal deficit, whereas we enjoy an historically high surplus. If those in the corporate sector continue to argue for further cuts to community services to get taxes down, we could suggest that they should start at their end, for instance, by removing tax deductability for salaries above $200,000.

It is in this context that the current push towards privatisation must be viewed. If anything demonstrates lack of vision and bankruptcy of intellectual analysis, it is the absolute faith in the private sector to do things better on every occasion. The fact is that there is absolutely no evidence to support such a contention. Its idea of the national interest is to ensure that any profitable public sector business is sold to the Government's mates and any consumer service obligation is simply left to lapse because it is not profitable. Yet the Commonwealth Bank, last month's victim, shows a better return on funds than its private competitors. Similarly, OTC Ltd shows a rate of return in excess of those achieved in the private sector and, according to OECD figures, delivers the cheapest overseas telephone calls in the world.

Compare that with the performance of the Bonds, the Skases and the Lowys, who managed to ruin a thriving television industry in a takeover spree lasting years. Compare that with at least $8 billion in non-performing loans in the private banking sector for which Australian families are now paying the bill. Then consider whether we can still say that private sector management is inherently more effective and efficient.

The Moomba-Sydney gas pipeline system is to be sold to the private sector despite the fact that it is a monopoly and can be used to hold gas consumers to ransom. Right now the Government is attempting to get around its contractual obligations to push up transmission costs to increase the pipeline's market price, a somewhat unedifying spectacle at the expense of private and industrial gas consumers in New South Wales.

Following the introduction of market principles, the users of telecommunications services in the United States and the United Kingdom are faced with price increases well in excess of the consumer price index. It will be no different here if the Treasurer cannot be stopped. Higher executive salaries, higher borrowing costs and the constant need to show short term profits will all be reflected in higher costs to the consumer. Meanwhile we retire debt at today's prices and give up a growing stream of revenue for future generations and a stake in strategic public interest industries like telecommunications and banking. Imagine the value today of significant Commonwealth involvement in the oil and aluminium industries. This was irrevocably terminated by the privatisation decisions of the Menzies Administration in 1953.

The community is seeking long term vision from its elected representatives, not short term Budget-driven decisions. The Treasurer's failure to lift revenue means that there is still an over-reliance on monetary policy despite his desperate pleas to the banks to drop rates. The one question to be asked here is: When will the Treasurer stop jawboning and refer the banks to the Prices Surveillance Authority to check their margins?

The Australian economy was in a similar position in the early 1950s. Excess demand contributed to a blow-out in the current account of similar proportions to the one currently facing us. The policy response was to increase taxation to stabilise this demand. Depending upon the type of taxation method utilised, this is a much more equitable method of demand restraint and certainly does not squeeze home buyers or cripple small business.

The other depressing aspect of the Budget was the total inaction on the continued decline in public infrastructure. This is happening while our cities are falling to bits and more people are joining the unemployment queues. The Australian people are seeking more and better services and it is they who deserve attention rather than the financiers. It is heartening to hear that at least one senior Government Minister shares this concern about the need for urban renewal.

Turning to the expenditure measures, we find some slight increases in various portfolios, but most also include some unfortunate policy decisions. In the health area, for example, the $2.50 pensioner prescription fee and the increase in the maximum patient contribution fee are regrettable and will be opposed by the Democrats.

The proposal to deem that certain deposits held by pensioners in financial institutions earn the minimum rate of interest of 10 per cent is symptomatic of the attitude of this Government-hit the poor, the pensioners and the low income earners. The emphasis should be on ending the effective subsidy which this arrangement has granted to the banks and other institutions, rather than putting pressure on an estimated 300,000 pensioners, arguably the most vulnerable section of our community. Many will not be able to rearrange their affairs, either through ignorance of the rules or a misunderstanding of their effect and will consequently face a cut in their pension.

The Democrats have announced their proposal to ensure that the banks, rather than the pensioners, should bear the burden of this provision. Our alternative proposal is for the Government to legislate to compel the financial institutions to pay at least the deemed rate of return on the appropriate deposits of pensioners and beneficiaries.

The Australian Democrats support the significant boost to corporate legislation that the Australian Securities Commission will provide. We will urge the Government to be unrelenting in its pursuit of corporate criminals. There are still many deficiencies in the legislation. For example, public company reporting must be improved by increasing the frequency of profit and loss statements and balance sheets; by the standardisation of all key financial indicators; by mandatory cash flow reporting; by much stricter disclosure regarding related party transactions and management fees paid to companies owned by directors; by the licensing of independent experts and the availability of class actions for share or unit holders. The Government must address these matters as a matter of urgency. Mr Hartnell's recent announcement on the range of amendments related to directors' responsibilities, unit trusts and insider trading is welcome.

Despite the Treasurer's failure to block tax avoidance loopholes, Commonwealth revenue is predicted to increase to more than $100 billion for the first time. This is a big Budget and it does contain some good news. Following the laudable measures to exclude full rate pensioners from the tax system altogether, part rate pensioners are now completely outside the provision of the tax system. This is a worthwhile achievement and one supported by the Democrats. However, this does not complete the total integration of the tax and social security systems for pensioners.

The Treasurer announced in last year's Budget that part rate pensioners would be completely exempt from taxation by 1995 and we will certainly keep him to that promise, but why must pensioners wait five years for this reform? If the Treasurer adopted some of our anti-tax avoidance proposals he would be able to achieve this reform much earlier.

However, we are also dismayed at some revenue measures. The proposed relaxation of the resource rent tax is alarming. By relaxing the strict permit area test that currently applies at a cost of $35m, the economic rent derived from the exploitation of the resources is in danger of escaping appropriate taxation. We concede that in the long term the switch to include Bass Strait in the RRT regime may well be revenue positive, but in current straitened circumstances the concessional treatment of exploration expenditure should have been funded by increasing the rate of the resource rent tax.

Similarly, the proposal to further weaken the new taxation of foreign source income rules is both unnecessary and indefensible. When times are as tight as the Government says they are, there should be no concessions to the international corporate sector. How favourable tax treatment to foreign buildings and industrial property can be part of a Budget that slugs chronically ill patients is something a Labor Government will have to explain, if it can.

The imputation and bad debts proposals are welcome, yet long overdue. The possible double dipping on overseas bad debts by financial institutions arises purely from a drafting oversight. Such technical problems arise frequently and are often exploited by scheming lawyers and accountants. This shows the need for an annual income tax technical corrections Act, as is the practice in the United States, to reverse such unintended consequences of new legislation.

The provisional tax anti-avoidance measure appears reasonable yet unnecessary as the income involved should have been subject to pay as you earn provisions and to penalty tax in the case of non-compliance. The zone rebate review, although limited, has identified and remedied some anomalies in the rebate and the decisions taken are supported. The decision to abolish the distinction between rebates available to residents residing in the special areas of zones A and B is a worthwhile simplification. One reprehensible measure, however, is the proposal to slash the value of the medical expenses rebate by nearly 30 per cent. The concession provides a vital safety net to ensure that taxpayers will not be bankrupted by huge medical expenses which they must meet personally. We will be pressing the Government to reconsider this harsh decision.

The capital gains tax rollover proposals concerning assets destroyed by natural disasters and temporary absence from a principal residence represent sensible decisions and are supported. However, in another area the review of income tax treatment of environmental related expenses is still not complete, holding up urgent reforms in that area. The completion of that review is keenly anticipated. Small business has no cause to be impressed with the Government's token response to the recommendations of the Beddall committee, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. However, the limited progress with respect to the timing of tax remittances is welcome. Apart from the need for immediate interest rate relief, the Government must introduce measures to protect small business lessees under the Trade Practices Act, to improve advisory services for small business, and to simplify the tax system as well as the other matters addressed in the Beddall committee report.

In summary, we have been offered a Budget which fails to deal with any of the big challenges facing Australia today. It makes no attempt to increase the capacity of individuals to lead more independent, useful and active lives. For that we would have needed better access to education for all and an increase in the free income limits for pensioners and beneficiaries.
There is no attempt to move us closer to the clever society. A substantial increase in the funds for scientific and postgraduate research would have been a good start.

There is no serious attempt to conserve energy or to change from cars and trucks to rail and public transport. This would require a national rail system and more funds for public transport, financed by a higher fuel excise and a road freight levy on trucks.

There is no evidence that the environment is more than a token issue for the Treasurer. To tackle the challenges here would involve land care, endangered species and habitat restoration programs and firm targets for the phasing out of chlorofluorocarbons and carbon dioxide emissions and also an international rainforest protection fund. Yet none of these are in this Budget to any effective degree.

There are few measures designed to help business play its part. Trade training, export market development, reduced interest rates and a stronger Trade Practices Act would all have made a start. Finally, there is no sign that the Treasurer is aware that his high interest rate policy has failed and that we need a higher surplus to reduce both the exchange rate and the cost of finance. The money for these and other urgently needed measures to ensure we move towards a socially stable, economically active and environmentally sound society could have come from plugging 22 tax avoidance loopholes, yielding some $2,600m; from taxes on wealthy individuals and corporations who are not now paying their way, yielding $2,085m; and from indirect tax increases, imposed on a selective basis, yielding $1,980m.

When the Labor Government has to resort to targeting pensioners, students, families and public assets to balance the books whilst there is still great injustice and inequality in our society, is it any wonder that more and more the public cannot distinguish between the major political parties and turn to the Australian Democrats for an alternative which is fair and just. It is an alternative which is also feasible, as the Democrats alternative Budget proposals have shown.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON MIGRATION REGULATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations I present the report of the Committee entitled Illegal Entrants in Australia-Balancing Control and Compassion. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This first report of the Committee contains one disclaimer from a member who was unable to attend any meetings of the Committee, and dissenting reports from five other Committee members. Before outlining the proposals in the report, I should like to make some introductory comments. The Committee was established by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand MP, with a wide ranging brief to consider changes to the Migration Act and regulations, and any other matter referred by the Minister.

As a priority the Committee decided to examine the difficult and sensitive issue of illegal entrants, given the pending end of the limited concessionary arrangements on 1 June and 30 June this year. These concessionary arrangements require illegals to, first, leave Australia, thereby not incurring any time penalty should they wish to reapply immediately for entry to Australia; or, secondly, apply to regularise their status on spouse or economic grounds.

This deadline was perceived by the Committee to create serious problems of implementation for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs of any recommendations requiring amendment and of potential injustice to some of those affected.

The Committee, upon deciding on this inquiry, considered that it could be thought to be unfair if some people were required to leave after 30 June and before the Committee had an opportunity to examine the problem and present a report of its findings to the Parliament. The Chairman of the Committee wrote to the Minister on 20 June this year arguing that, while not wishing to encourage illegal entrants currently here to remain, the Committee was seeking further evidence in respect of these matters, and therefore requested an extension of time beyond the current 1 June and 30 June dates until 30 September 1990 for the concessionary arrangements now applicable and for voluntary departure without re-entry restrictions.

The Minister agreed to extend the concessionary period until 31 October 1990 and, in doing so, emphasised that this would be the final deadline. At this point I must emphasise that the amended Act and regulations came into effect on 19 December last year. The new regime was effective from that date and not, as has been reported, from 31 October this year. A very limited concession was introduced on 15 January 1990 and extended several times to finish finally on 31 October. I said `a very limited concession' because very few people qualify to remain under the concessionary arrangements. Those who can qualify do so on spouse or economic grounds and if the Minister is satisfied that there are compelling reasons for the grant of a permit.

The numbers applying to take advantage of the concessionary arrangements are low. However, the concession does not extend to those people here illegally and who choose to leave prior to 31 October 1990 who will not incur a time penalty should they choose to re-apply for entry.

The Committee further determined that it would report as early as possible in September in order to give the Minister and Cabinet adequate time to consider the report and to draft any necessary legislative amendments. The Committee members now recognise that this extremely tight reporting deadline has imposed severe and near impossible constraints on the Committee, particularly its secretariat and our adviser. The Committee is of the view that, if it is required to meet such severe time constraints in the future, we will have to determine guidelines that are more reasonable. The resources presently allocated to the Committee are not adequate to meet such tight schedules. Even without the severe deadlines, the issue that the Committee has been formed to examine, migration regulations, is extremely complex and detailed and the Committee is therefore deserving of resources adequate to the task.

Widespread interest has been shown in the inquiry, with over 90 submissions having been received. The Committee held public hearings in Melbourne, Canberra and Sydney and consulted with a large number of community groups as well as the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Australia's migration laws have been developed to control the entry and stay of non-citizens in Australia. There is, therefore, a need to maintain the Government's migration program within predetermined levels and to facilitate the removal of persons who are either illegally in Australia or whose presence in Australia is not in the best interests of the Australian community.

However, there is also a need to consider some of the cases of those people here illegally prior to 19 December 1989 when the law changed so dramatically and where it can be shown that their case merits consideration. The Committee does not condone or encourage illegality as a backdoor entry to permanent entry to Australia. It supports the efforts of the Government and the Department to, firstly, minimise current levels of illegal entry and, secondly, prevent a future problem.

In these circumstances a majority of the Committee believes that some limited opportunity should be made available for a small proportion of the total number of illegals to regularise their status. The majority report is concerned with some of these people who may be innocently illegal-those who have a compelling compassionate case or those who have been absorbed into Australian society for at least five years and can show that they have made a substantial contribution to Australia. It is suggested that a limited window of opportunity would encourage people to come forward before 31 October and would help to minimise the extent of the illegal twilight society.

A majority of the Committee believes that the main way of dealing with the problem of long term illegal immigrants generally is by empowering the Immigration Review Tribunal to consider applications from illegal immigrants who come forward or who are apprehended before 31 October this year. It is suggested that, in the case of innocent illegals, the Tribunal be empowered to make recommendations to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, but in all other cases to be able to make a determination.

A special category of people which the Committee is particularly concerned about is those people who are now illegal or who in the future may become illegal through no fault of their own. The Committee is unanimous in its concern about this particular category of people, the innocent illegals.

It is important to note that people can become illegal entrants even if they are honest in their dealings with immigration staff, have no knowledge of their illegality, or have no intention of becoming an illegal. Certain children born or residing in Australia fall into this category. The Committee argues that an innocent illegal should have the opportunity to regularise his or her status.

All members of the Committee, with the exception of myself, are of the view that the Immigration Review Tribunal should consider the cases of innocent illegals and other cases of compassion. An expanded role for the Tribunal is therefore recommended. The majority of the Committee further recommends that illegal entrants should be able to apply to the Tribunal where they:
(a) believe themselves to be an innocent illegal immigrant, as defined in chapter 3; or,
(b) meet the following conditions:
(i) have been in Australia for at least five years prior to 31 October 1990 (that is arrived in Australia prior to 31 October 1985) and are able to present evidence demonstrating this fact; and
(ii) have come forward and presented themselves to the registrar of the Immigration Review Tribunal before 31 October 1990.

In making its determination, the Tribunal will take note of the following relevant circumstances which are adopted from British immigration rules: age, length of residence in Australia, strength of connections with Australia, personal history including character, conduct and employment record, domestic circumstances, compassionate circumstances, and any representations received on the person's behalf. A major issue of concern to the whole Committee which particularly affects innocent illegals is the requirement in regulation 42 which states:
Where an applicant for an entry permit is illegal, that application has been lodged not more than 12 months after becoming illegal.

Innocent illegals are predominantly children or those who are unaware of their illegal status. The illegality may not be discovered until many years after the time they became illegal, yet they will be caught by regulation 42, no matter what their circumstances may be. The Committee has recommended in chapter 5 of its report that a provision for a waiver of the time period for lodgment of an application in appropriate circumstances be incorporated into the regulations.

On pages 73 and 74 of the report, an assessment is given of the total number likely to be successful in an application to remain in Australia if this process is adopted. Of the 90,000 illegal entrants presently in Australia, between 3,000 and 4,000 may be able to stay. The majority report rejects the argument that this concession will establish a precedent and that people will be encouraged to hide away for five years.

The Committee believes that the Government must demonstrate that it is serious about enforcing the 31 October deadline. It must publicise the fact and, in doing so, encourage people to come forward by that date. It should point out that they will suffer penalties and that no further concessions will be available in the future. It is because of the severity of the scheme after 31 October 1990 that the majority of the Committee has recommended that this one-off concession be made.

On behalf of those senators who served on the Committee, I want to express gratitude to Dr Kathryn Cronin, the legal consultant to the Committee. Dr Cronin's dedication, professionalism and expertise were highly valued by the Committee. I would also like to thank the staff of the secretariat, Robina Mills and Heidi Quinlan. Members of the Committee recognise the work they have done in the last few weeks in order that this report could reach the Parliament at an early date.

It might be more appropriate to apologise to Kathryn, Robina and Heidi and their respective families for the enormous pressure we have put upon them in the recent past. The fact that the report has been delivered on time is a real identification of their commitment and loyalty to the Parliament and the Committee. This loyalty required long hours of work that severely intruded into their personal lives. This would have placed intolerable strains on their families. I reinforce the earlier comment that the Committee is under-resourced and request that the matter be addressed at an early date.

As I said at the beginning of this speech, the Committee was divided in its conclusions. We were divided across party lines, between the two Houses and between parties. We were forced to take sides. After much deliberation and soul searching, I came down on the side of people who seek to enter Australia by legal means. As a representative of Western Australia, I felt that I had an obligation to represent the views of constituents in my State who were desperately seeking to have family members join them in this wonderful country. I came down against those who abuse our laws and treat our migration system with contempt. I do not agree that law-breakers should be given advantage over those who comply with the laws and treat the system with respect.
I repeat the quote in the introduction to chapter 2 of the Committee's report:

Australia's immigration system limits the number of immigrant visas available. There is a long waiting list of applicants seeking migrant entry. For each immigrant who secures a visa by fraud or each illegal entrant permitted to remain, other qualified applicants may be left behind or left to wait longer for a visa. Illegal immigration severely taxes resources of immigration staff and may undermine the political resolve needed to maintain an expansive immigration program.
I make no apologies for repeating this quote. I quoted the paragraph twice in my dissenting report, and I will repeat it again and again during the debate on the illegal entrant question. I repeat:
For each immigrant who secures a visa by fraud or each illegal entrant permitted to remain, other qualified applicants may be left behind or left to wait longer for a visa.
That sentence is a very important statement, and it was an unanimous statement of the Committee. Honourable senators should remember the preceding sentence:
There is a long waiting list of applicants seeking migrant entry.

It was the meaning and intent of these sentences and this paragraph that encouraged me not to agree with the majority report to create and open up another can of worms in immigration. I call the Committee's recommendation on the Immigration Review Tribunal only a can of worms. I do that because of the respect in which I hold my Committee colleagues. But I suspect that constituents, residents and citizens of Australia will use much stronger language when they hear and fully comprehend the recommendations of the majority of the Committee.

I warn the Senate and the people of Australia not to be misled by the low estimation given by the Committee that only 3,000 to 4,000 illegals will be allowed to settle under its proposal. The figure could be much higher, and honourable senators can be assured that it will grow in future years as the precedent for absorption becomes enshrined once again in our system.

Whether it is fair or equal, just or moral, illegals will come to accept that if they stay hidden for five years, or however many years is determined, they will look for a reward. That reward will be permanent residency in this country. It will be a reward given at the expense of a person who waits patiently in a queue in Bombay, Athens, Moscow, London, Harare, Beirut, Seoul, Afghanistan, Sri Lanka, Rome, Washington or even Dublin, or from wherever potential migrants to Australia will apply.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Hobart?

—No, I think the Hobart people are doing very well. I thank Senator Cooney for his interjection. Honourable senators should remember that those people in cities right across the world are competing for places in a smaller pool. The migrant intake for 1991 has been reduced by 10 per cent from last year's level. There are now only 126,000 places available. The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs supplied the Committee with evidence that some 90,000 illegals are currently in this country. Relative to Australia's total population, that figure could be considered to be tiny. However, put in its proper perspective, it represents nearly 75 per cent of the annual intake of migrants and makes one realise that Australia is experiencing a major problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The 90,000 figure that I use is the one provided to the Committee by the Department. According to the Department's calculation it represents the number of illegals in Australia at 30 April this year. The figure for July last year was 60,000. I am aware that the Department's figures have been questioned in other places by other authorities. There are those who put the current figure as high as 150,000. For the purpose of this debate I shall accept the Department's figures and use the official figures to highlight the 30,000 increase that occurred between July of last year and April this year. That amazing increase of 50 per cent occurred during only nine months under what the Committee Chairman, Dr Theophanous, described as a tough regime and during what was again described by the Chair as the biggest round-up of illegals since the war.

Presently in Australia there are 90,000 people who do not believe they live under a tough regime and they are not scared off by a round-up. They just think it is a joke and they treat the rules and laws with contempt. They do not believe the Government's strong words. As I said on page 3 of my dissenting report, the initial concessions and the three later extensions since granted have been interpreted as a lack of resolve on behalf of the Government to implement its tough provisions on apprehension, detention and deportation. Illegals know that sections of the media will sensationalise deportation stories when they inevitably happen. Graphic coverage has been provided in the past. Sometimes those stories generate public sympathy, and some illegals and a variety of organisations have sought to pressure the Government not to proceed with its actions in regard to deportation.

In the past illegals have sought to use this pressure and gain sympathy to remain here. It is undoubtedly a powerful tool to use against whichever government is in office at the time, and there is no doubt that that pressure is keenly felt by many people, including the local member of parliament. Those people, now 90,000 in total, were told in December 1988-nearly two years ago-that the Government was going to crack down on the illegal entrants problem. The then Minister for Immigration gave illegals a clear and unambiguous warning that the Government was going to tighten the provisions. He said he would adopt measures consistent with the recommendations of the Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies-the FitzGerald report. In recommendation 54, which was presented to the Parliament more than two years ago, Dr FitzGerald said:

Anyone who is illegally in Australia by unauthorised stay beyond the expiry of a visa or by illegal entry should forfeit the right to apply for immigration while here or be automatically rejected if they have already applied.

That is the recommendation made to the Government by Dr FitzGerald after an intensive inquiry. Those illegals, who now number at least 90,000, did not believe it. In fact they directly challenge the Government. They do not accept that the Government has the right-indeed the obligation-to determine Australia's immigration program. They as individuals decide for themselves who can come to Australia and who should remain here. They challenge the integrity of our immigration system. They should not be given any advantage over other potential migrants who pursue the proper course of action. The proposal to allow illegals, albeit a small number, access to the Immigration Review Tribunal is ill-conceived and ill-considered. It gives long term offenders an advantage over other people and it has the potential to choke and stifle the work of the Immigration Review Tribunal.

Even if the Government accepts the proposal, I have grave doubts that the machinery necessary to implement the proposal could be put in place by 31 October. Even if this could be achieved, a major publicity campaign would need to be mounted in order to ensure that all illegals are aware of the further concession. I suggest that such a campaign should be engaged in, but for a different purpose.

In my dissenting report I recommend that the Government use all methods of communication with all sections of the media. I make particular reference to the ethnic and foreign language media, although I do not want to point the finger at any particular nationality which may be currently abusing our system. It is of note that, according to the Department's figures, the major abusers of this system actually come from the United Kingdom rather than a country which, perhaps, does not have such close links with Australia. I am not necessarily pointing the finger at any particular ethnic body or nation, but it will be important for every sector of the community, even those people who do not speak or understand English, to be aware of what the Government intends to do in just over six weeks when the final deadline of 31 October is reached. All illegals and their supporters-and there are many of them, judging from the evidence the Committee received during its inquiry-should be aware that the Government will crack down. Government must engage in this publicity campaign.

The Committee's report was tabled in the other place on Tuesday of this week and since its tabling I have been heartened by the commendations that I have received for the remarks in my dissenting report. Those commendations, I might add, did not come only from colleagues in my own political party, the Labor Party; they also came from my parliamentary colleagues from other political parties as well.

I am also pleased to note that the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) is now calling upon the Government to crack down on illegals. The ACTU is particularly concerned with those who are here illegally and are working. According to estimates that the Department gave to the Committee during the inquiry, I would guess that some 60,000 illegals are further compounding their illegal status in Australia by engaging in full time employment.

The question of illegals is a huge one for Australia. Of greater concern is the fact that it is a growing problem, judging from statistics that the Department gave to the Committee. I highlight the fact that there is some dissent concerning the figures that the Department has supplied. I indicated earlier in my speech that there are sources in our community that estimate the problem to involve 150,000 people, rather than the 90,000 that the Department estimates. Whatever the figure-be it only 90,000 or 150,000-it constitutes a direct challenge to the integrity of Australia's immigration system.

I am particularly concerned that advantage is being given to people who take the law into their own hands and decide for themselves that they are the ones who should settle in Australia. I think it is the job of government to make the necessary rules and regulations in order to determine who is suited here. If we go along with some of the suggestions-and some groups made extreme suggestions during the inquiry-to allow perhaps open slather on illegals, it would certainly resolve the problem momentarily, but if we did it once it would open the flood gates.

Immigration is a big debate in Australia at the moment, particularly with regard to the number of people who should be allowed to come here. The Government cut the number by 10 per cent earlier this year, and the figure is now 126,000. There is argument from some sources that we should have a nil immigration figure. I do not accept that and I also do not accept that, whatever the number of people that come in, it is the individual who should determine who should or should not settle here. That is the job of government and it is the job in front of each and every one of us, as political representatives.

We have given clear warning over two years. There have been many articles and programs on radio and television to say that the illegals will sooner or later have to leave Australia. They have had two years' warning. If we buckle under yet again we will only be compounding the problem. Others have seen the concessions we have made so far as a sign of weakness and have interpreted them as an indication that the Government is not willing to bite the bullet and follow through its own policies using the laws that have been given to it by the Parliament. If we weaken yet again, I think Australia's immigration program will be in grave danger of falling into an enormous heap. I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion and, in so doing, wish to state briefly the reasons why the Australian Democrats support the majority report.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that the neglect of previous governments has left Australia with an unsustainable legacy of illegal entrants, estimated variously at between 90,000 and 150,000. We agree that this number must be reduced. Hence, we support tough measures to apprehend and deport illegal entrants. We also agree that this is necessary to protect the integrity of our immigration program. To the extent that we allow queue jumpers to get away with breaking the law, we reduce our capacity to receive refugees and family reunion migrants who are taking their turn in the normal manner and in the approved process.

However, the Government's attempt last year to codify Australia's immigration laws has produced a rigid and oppressive body of legislation which makes it virtually impossible to take account of individual circumstances where the strict application of the law would produce unjustifiable hardship.

In years gone by the Minister for immigration was able to use his or her discretion in such matters. However, as I said, the codification attempt has made that virtually impossible. We have had cases which obviously merited special consideration. One, without naming names, is that of a young person who arrived here with his parents, who came here as illegal migrants. That young person was not aware of his parents status or, consequently, his own. He attended school in Australia all his life. He was dux of his school, was ready to enter a professional career, was engaged to be married and yet was deported to a country where he no longer had any ties-social, educational or personal. In such instances we must provide a window of opportunity, if you like, for our system to be tempered with some compassion.

I believe that it is essential to provide a mechanism to allow our system to take account of such exceptional circumstances. Unless that is done, our legal system will be brought into disrepute, people who deserve compassionate consideration will be driven underground, and we will compound the problem of illegal migrants. If people feel they have no chance at all, yet they have compelling and compassionate circumstances that force them to stay here-for instance, to help some aged or ailing relative-then they will try to evade the law. We believe that after 30 October such exceptions should be-and indeed, if the Committee's recommendations are accepted, will be-at an absolute minimum. But prior to 31 October we must find the means to reduce the current undesirable level of illegal immigrants.

We have these two problems: firstly, what do we do in the future? We believe that we should be tough, both in admitting migrants and in enforcing our compliance regulations. Secondly, we must deal with the people who are illegally here now, and consider how we can reduce that level.

If the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations are accepted, our goal will be achieved by a carrot and stick approach. Illegal entrants leaving Australia voluntarily before 31 October will be able to reapply from abroad without any time restrictions. Illegal entrants apprehended after 31 October will suffer time restrictions on their ability to apply, and, in addition, will have to meet all costs associated with being deported. In fact, in recognition of that we are informed that several thousand people have already chosen to leave to avoid these disadvantages.

The Australian Democrats support the recommendation to empower the Immigration Review Tribunal to consider applications from people who believe they are innocent illegal entrants-people who have entered Australia and stayed here not knowing they are illegal; people in a similar situation to the person in the example I quoted earlier of children who arrive here with their parents, unaware of their parents' circumstances.

Also, we believe that an exception should be granted to enable people who have been here more than five years to apply. It is not a blanket suggestion or condition that leads to their being given permission to stay; it is a threshold requirement-the majority report suggests-which would enable them to apply and have their cases considered. Applicants who apply under this exception will also have to satisfy public interest criteria, and will be required to demonstrate that they have made a positive and substantial contribution to Australia. Also, they will have to show that there are compelling compassionate circumstances which contributed to their illegal standing, and which should be taken into account as reasons for granting permanent residence.

To portray these exceptions as an overall amnesty is, therefore, quite erroneous and, in some cases, I believe even mischievous. I believe that the totality of the approach laid down by the majority report acknowledges the need for tight controls, but tempers this approach with compassion for people who deserve consideration on public policy and humanitarian grounds. It should be noted that these exceptions-out of a total of, say, 150,000 illegal entrants-would only affect 10,000 or 11,000 and fewer than half are expected to apply. This means that we are only talking about 1 to 2 per cent of people who deserve some specific consideration out of the total illegal entrants in this country. The Democrats support the majority recommendation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations which prepared this report entitled Illegal Entrants in Australia-Balancing Control and Compassion. I was one of those who dissented. Although a number of the 10 people on the Committee dissented, I think the general thrust of the report-balancing control and compassion-was accepted by all those who attended the meetings. The honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) was unable to attend any of the Committee meetings. He took no part in the deliberations on this report, and has made that clear in it.

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that the dissensions and the differing opinions expressed by people on the Committee arose from the problem of what should be done in what really is an impossible situation. Australia is a big country-a country we can all be proud of-but, unfortunately, it is not big enough to take in all those who want to come here, so choices must be made.

The difficulty is that the choice is not between the good and the deserving and the bad and the undeserving, but between the many people who are good and deserving and who can put forward the most heart-rending of cases in support of an application to come here. Indeed, illegal immigrants, in most cases, can put forward a proposition to stay here that is supported by evidence indicating that it would be a harsh decision to deport them. This Committee, this Parliament and, indeed, this country have to wrestle with the constant difficulty of who amongst these decent people who simply want to come here for a better life, and to make a contribution to this country, should be allowed to stay. The same applies in the case of illegal immigrants who want to stay here so that they can pursue a life that they find attractive and at the same time make a contribution to this country.

In this situation, how are we to choose who will stay and who will not? In the end, every member of the Committee came down on the side of those who make applications to come to Australia according to due process. I, for one, have a lot of sympathy for people who come here as temporary visitors, find the place attractive, and want to stay. I do not believe it is a heinous crime to be attracted to this country and to want to stay, but it is wrong to do so without going through the proper processes. It is for that reason that those who do so must take second place to those who go through the proper processes. As a nation, we face great difficulties in deciding who will be allowed to come here. The point is not whether a person who has come here illegally is deserving of the right to stay here, but whether that person should take priority over a person who has made a proper application; that is the real question.

There is the proposition that any person who stays here illegally denies a place to those who have applied properly. There has been a denial of that proposition as it has been said that people who are here illegally do not go into the numbers of those people who come here as legal immigrants; therefore, it is a false argument to say that a place taken by an illegal immigrant denies that place to a person who applies properly. The Government has made it quite clear that that is not true and that people who are here illegally do deny a place to those who want to come here legitimately.

Perhaps the person most in the hot seat in this area is the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand). When one thinks about the choices he has to make and the program he has to run, one can have considerable sympathy for him because making choices in these situations is a terrible burden.

All people on the Committee impressed me with the dedication they showed in trying to grapple with an impossible problem. I also join Senator McKiernan in giving high praise to our legal consultant, Dr Kathryn Cronin, and the staff, Robina Mills, Heidi Quinlan and Francis Kleiss. I think that they performed their duties in a most outstanding way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Above and beyond the call of duty.

—Above and beyond the call of duty; I agree with that entirely. I think that the report clearly illustrates the tragedy, I suppose, at the heart of the immigration debate. It is a tragedy and a problem that cannot, I think, be solved satisfactorily. The best we can do is to try to impose standards of fairness and equity. In my opinion, that can best be done by giving priority to those who come here according to a legitimate process but at the same time extending compassion to those cases which any decent reasonable person would say should be placed into the category of people who show exceptional reasons for being able to stay here.
