SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill is to facilitate and encourage the amalgamation of unions. It is clearly being introduced by the Government in response to very great concerns in the union movement about its declining support from the traditional base that it relies upon. This problem was identified very starkly by Mr Kelty in May of 1987 when he produced a document called Future Strategies for the Trade Union Movement. He admitted then that the union movement was in decline for a number of reasons, which were identified, and he then strongly promoted the view that the number of unions in Australia should be reduced from over 300, as they then were, to about 20.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly the situation has not improved from the unions' point of view since then. Indeed, in the private sector the strength of union membership has declined to an all-time low of 32 per cent of those employed in the sector. Union membership has declined particularly badly-from its point of view-among the young, casual workers, women and particularly in the rapidly growing service sector of the economy.

This is obviously a very real problem facing the union movement. Only now, because of that campaign by the union movement, is the Government taking action to effectively give, in the legislation, recognition to the problem and to provide a solution along the lines which the union movement itself is calling for.

This legislation has been dressed up by the Government as an improvement to the industrial relations process. In his second reading speech the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) referred to the number of independent inquiries over the last 10 or 15 years which have found that there are too many unions and that fewer unions would be a major advantage in improving the industrial relations climate in Australia.

The Minister has fallen back upon a view which has been fashionable over the last 15 years or so-that is, that there are too many unions, that they are all old-fashioned craft based notions of a past age and that it would be better if employees were herded together in a very small number of large unions which would be industry based.

Although the Minister has referred to a number of independent reports which have put forward that view, the Minister does not refer to the fact that there have been some other, more up-to-date and very different views expressed in recent times by people and organisations who also have some authority in this area.

It is interesting that the Minister did not mention the report of the Business Council of Australia of October last year on enterprise based bargaining units. He did not mention the views of the National Institute of Labour Studies which were expressed in its bulletin of December last year. He did not make any mention of a recent report of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development which also referred to Australia's union structures.

If we look at these views we will find that they are very different from the one that the Minister put forward as the solution-the view that big is beautiful and is the best solution. These people are very knowledgeable on the subject and they suggest a very different solution, namely, that there should be a focus on enterprise based unions.

A problem which the Opposition has very clearly identified is the number of unions in the workplace. The simple creation of large unions, even though there might be fewer total unions, will not necessarily mean that there will be any significant reduction in the number of unions which have representation in the workplace. That is the hub of the problem. The average number of unions per workplace at present is five. Even in small enterprises the owner may have to deal with a number of unions. If we have fewer unions, this may lead to fewer in each workplace, but there will still be an undue number of unions represented in each workplace.

Indeed, in some larger workplaces in Australia there are more than 10 unions that have to be dealt with. Again, if one simply creates fewer but very much bigger unions and still organises them on the same old craft-based occupation notion, it is not obvious that that will really make any significant or worthwhile difference to this basic problem. It is pretty widely recognised that the real problem is the number of unions which are represented at the workplace. Previously the concern has been the number within industry, but now, nevertheless, the recognition is more on the problem in the workplace or the enterprise itself. That, rather than the large number of unions, is really the hub of the concern.

This notion that, as a contribution to our better industrial relations processes, there should be fewer unions is also said to be established in other countries. A particular example is Germany. For many years in that country there had been something like only 20 unions. I think it is perhaps 19 at the moment. Because Germany has been a great economic success and still has one of the really strong economies of the world, there is seen to be some connection with the fact that it has fewer unions.

On the other hand, the other great successful economy of the Western world is Japan's. In Japan there is a totally different union structure based on enterprises. There are hundreds of unions in Japan based upon the enterprise unit.

I remember many years ago when this idea of amalgamations and fewer unions became popular. Germany was presented as the country that had the solution to the industrial relations problem. I happened to be on a study tour to Germany to discuss this particular subject, which I did with a leading union official. To my utter surprise, that official gave all sorts of very interesting and sound reasons why industrial relations were better in Germany than they were in other parts of the world and particularly in the United Kingdom. But he did not see the fact that Germany had a few large unions as the reason for better industrial relations in that country. I was very struck by that response at the time and very surprised, particularly in view of all the rhetoric we were hearing in Australia. It is now something like 15 years later, and we still have this Government pursuing the rhetoric that a few large unions will really be the solution to our industrial relations problems. As I say, that reasoning is totally contradicted by the Japanese experience and, on the basis of my own discussion some years ago, it did not seem to be accepted even by a union leader in Germany as the real reason why its industrial relations and processes were more successful than those of other countries.

The Opposition will be opposing the second reading of this legislation. We have objections to it based on the grounds that we do not believe that it is likely to be successful. It is also contrary to the solutions which we as the Opposition believe are the ones to our industrial relations problems.

I will run briefly through the reasons why the Opposition is opposing this Bill. It is promoting amalgamations for its own sake. It is not addressing amalgamations in the context of the problem of craft or occupational-based unions, which is really one of the major problems. The Bill is not going to actually solve that.

The Bill may result in a greater reduction in the number of industry focused unions instead of a reduction in the number of craft or occupation based unions. As I have already said, it will not really solve the problem of too many unions in the workplace and it will-this is prob- ably the most worrying aspect-deliver industries into the hands of militant left wing unions in a number of cases, strengthening the position of those militant unions. When this is combined with compulsory unionism it will, of course, make it even more difficult for unionists to have a choice of membership, or indeed for employees to have a choice of membership, because it will place greater power in the unions with individuals being further dragooned and their interests, of course, ignored.

It is not just the Opposition saying these things about this proposal. I refer to the views of Laurie Short, one of the most respected unionists in Australia. His comments on this proposal are reported in the IPA Review of December 1989. First of all, he believes that the Kelty plan is `an impossible dream and is focusing on the wrong issue'. He says-I have already dealt with this-that the size and number is irrelevant to the diagnosis of the terminal illness the union movement is suffering. He mentions two different concepts, in Japan and Germany. The views of another highly respected unionist in Australia, the former Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Union, Mr Joe Thompson, are also recorded in a recent article in the Review. He said this about the Kelty plan:

The net result could well be to give the ACTU greater power to pursue whatever political objectives its Executive decided upon-and an increased potential for large-scale disputes based on such objectives.
Mr Thompson concluded:

With 20 mega unions of the type envisaged by Mr Kelty it can clearly be seen that industrial power and muscle would exist to virtually force every worker in industry to join one of these mega unions under the threat of no jobs and no work if they refused.

So the Opposition's second concern is that not only will this proposal lead to this greater concentration of power in unions really of the same sort as we have come to know them in our system, many of which have become larger and militant already, but that we will be simply strengthening their position and not addressing the real problem. We also have very great concern about this because if in fact this legislation goes through, if it does go according to plan-hopefully Mr Laurie Short's views will prevail-it will, as I say, probably result in a worse industrial relations climate and system than we have at the moment. The only possible reason for the Government moving in this direction is either that it is simply doing the bidding of its masters in the Australian Council of Trade Unions or that it is looking to solutions which are now well and truly out of date.

Our second concern about it is that, if we go down this path of creating these larger unions, it will make it much more difficult to develop in the future a new union structure which will be enterprise based. I have already indicated the arguments about the need for improved industrial relations which would occur if at the workplace there were fewer unions, or preferably only one union, covering the employees in that workplace. That is an ideal which the Opposition espouses. As I have said, it is the experience in one of the world's most successful economies, namely, Japan. This is clearly the problem in Australia, as identified by so many people. I do not think the Government would deny that there are too many unions in the workplace.

One of the arguments for introducing this legislation was to have fewer unions in the workplace. But we will still have a number of unions in most workplaces. This legislation is presented more as getting unions focused on an industry basis rather than reducing the number in the workplace. I know that one of the new objectives of the Industrial Relations Act is to encourage and facilitate the development of organisations particularly by reducing the number of organisations in an industry or enterprise. But it mentions only reducing the number. Even if that were successful, there would still be too many in any one workplace. The reason is that the really basic structure of unionism in Australia, namely, the old craft or occupation concept, is not addressed in this legislation-and it will not be addressed simply by herding more employees into perhaps fewer but certainly very much larger unions. That will probably make industrial relations even more difficult because the employers, the managers, will not be dealing face to face with their employees but with remote union bureaucrats; if they are of a militant character, as many of them will be, it will just make it very much more difficult to establish the sort of harmony in the workplace that is the object of Opposition policy.

We have some other objections to this legislation that I will run through fairly briefly in the time left. It seems probable that the process of amalgamation over the next few years will of itself create more industrial unrest because the process will be resisted by a large number of the unions, not only the small unions. There will be big fights between the already big unions about who will get the cover as it is unlikely that they will be able to carve it up amongst themselves. If they do, that will be another problem that will be solved behind closed doors.

It should be remembered that even at the moment when we have about 300 unions there is in the Act a threshold for union membership of 1,000 members. Nearly half of our existing unions already have well below that threshold of 1,000 members. There is a section in the Industrial Relations Act which permits the Industrial Relations Commission to allow small unions to continue. There is a lot of evidence that people will wish to preserve their own corner and that there will be a great deal of debate, discussion and industrial unrest over this process that the Government is setting in train.

If unions are of a great size, there will be less flexibility and less communication with their membership and will certainly be very difficult for the particular circumstances of each workplace to be given any consideration. In the future, unions must play a much smaller role in negotiations. Amalgamations will probably happen for the wrong reasons. In many cases they will reflect particular traditional union rivalry, factionalism or, indeed, the Labor Party's own priorities and factionalism.

The Government should tell us how it proposes to justify the impact on the right to freedom of association. No doubt the Australian Democrats in this place will be very concerned about this aspect of the legislation, because people will be required to join large organisations and refused the right-I doubt that it will happen-to have smaller organisations. Freedom of choice is an internationally recognised human right and the Opposition strongly believes in that right.

Finally-I have already made the point that the Bill is essentially a gift to the Australian Council of Trade Unions-it is the ACTU solution to the problem. It is not necessarily the best solution to the problem, the one in the national interest. The Government is simply giving a legislative rubber stamp to the solutions suggested by Mr Kelty, in particular, and the ACTU.

Another problem that should be mentioned-and this will be dealt with more particularly at the committee stage-is that the legislation, in order to encourage this amalgamation, will weaken the secret ballot process and it will weaken the views of the less powerful unions and groups of employees in the community. There are, therefore, a great many objections to this legislation.

This is not simply a doctrinaire reaction by the Opposition based upon rigid adherence to Opposition policy. Clearly, the Opposition is very concerned about the impact of this legislation on the implementation of our policy when we are returned to government and the amount of unscrambling that will have to be done. This legislation will make the implementation of our policies more difficult. That is a very serious consideration.

The Opposition is opposed to this legislation basically because it does not address the real problem of industrial relations in this country. It probably does not really address the problem of declining unionism in this country unless, of course, the power that is to be given to the bigger unions will mean that they will be able to dragoon more people into union membership simply by muscle rather than by persuasion. That may be the real reason for the legislation. It is probably Mr Kelty's aim. It may well be the real reason the Government is introducing this legislation, which does not address the problem of industrial relations processes in this country. For those reasons, the Opposition opposes the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. I will begin my comments in very general terms by looking at the industrial relations scene that we have seen unfolding in Western society over the last 10 years. I will then state the broad position of the Australian Democrats on industrial relations and move on to the specific provisions of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The last decade has seen rapid change in industrial relations in Western society. Australia was relatively slow to respond, but there are now a number of clear trends which will usher in great and significant change. We can probably discern a number of quite specific trends which are well and truly under way in the industrial relations scene in this country.

There has been a real decline in union membership and influence and I think it is legitimate for unions to address that. A process of union amalgamation has been under way for some years-and the specific intention of this Bill is to accelerate that process-complemented by a process of award restructuring, and those two processes must be seen together if there is to be any real understanding of what the Government is attempting to achieve through this Bill.

Another discernible trend has been an emphasis upon enterprise bargaining. This is the trend which the Opposition cites as the one it would like to see as the most dominant in the next decade. As a part of that process, there is an emphasis on productivity in the workplace. The economic circumstances of Australia are such that that emphasis is very appropriate. So those five broad thrusts and areas of concern can be identified.

Two legitimate models of industrial relations have prevailed in Western countries, and they have been cited by Senator Durack. He has chosen to emphasise his preference for one. The first of these two legitimate models prevailing in Western society, generally referred to as the centralised model, which the Hawke Government has enacted, is dependent upon an accord between unions, management and government and its chief objective is economic restraint.

The second industrial relations model is that proposed by the conservative parties which sees a deregulated labour market where groups of employees, or even individuals, negotiate both pay and conditions within a framework directed by government and supervised by an industrial relations commission. In this model, there is an emphasis upon productivity. Senator Durack has cited Germany and Japan as examples of those two industrial relations models.

I wish to clarify the position of the Australian Democrats in relation to those two models and state our preferences. By doing this, I hope it will become obvious why we take the position that we do in relation to this Bill. As the party holding the balance of power in the Senate, the Democrats are in a position to influence critically the legislation enacted and, hence, the model that will prevail in the 1990s. We take that responsibility very seriously indeed. The bottom line is that the Democrats have very serious reservations about a deregulated labour market. In a stressed economy, such as Australia will inevitably be in the 1990s, there is great potential for a labour market out of control, one in which there will be big winners and big losers. We therefore favour retention of a centralised controlling authority, namely, the Industrial Relations Commission, with the responsibility of overseeing and maximising justice, harmony and best economic outcomes.

Without apology, we identify with the centralised model. We see the inherent dangers of the decentralised model as having big winners and big losers. To put it in more precise terms, we might see executives of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) doing very well from a decentralised model; however, the tea ladies and the cleaners may do considerably worse. Within the framework that we favour, that of the centralised model and the overseeing role of a strong Industrial Relations Commission, the Democrats will support the processes of amalgamation, award restructuring, industrial democracy and increased productivity through diversity of agreements at industry, enterprise and individual levels. However, we believe that all of these should be subject to approval by the Industrial Relations Commission.

Irrespective of which model is pursued by government, this Government or subsequent governments, the Australian Democrats will seek industrial relations legislation which meets the following criteria. We will seek legislation which, firstly, acknowledges the need for and is complemented by a national income support scheme; and, secondly, avoids such divergences in pay and work conditions as to polarise the community, with minorities trapped in poverty. We see that as an inherent danger of the decentralised model. We will seek legislation which, thirdly, constrains wage growth to responsible levels and maximises worker participation and cooperation between management and labour; fourthly, protects hard-won benefits such as leave, safety and superannuation; and, fifthly, facilitates award restructuring and union amalgamations, where supported by the membership. That is an important qualification, which I shall address in a few moments.

The final criterion that we would apply in deciding whether or not to support legislation is whether the legislation requires compulsory registration and public perusal of all agreements, be they between employer and union or work council and individual. We believe that, if circumstances arose whereby individuals went behind closed doors and negotiated their own precise and specific deals with their employer, there would begin the process of erosion of all of those dimensions that give rise to justice, social justice and equality in this country, hard-won as they have been over a long period.

There are several areas of concern under the general heading of industrial relations that I believe will be addressed specifically by this Parliament. This will be a critical Parliament in relation to industrial relations. The first of those areas is the purpose of this Bill. In other words the general area of amalgamation and restructuring will be the first area of reform addressed during the term of this Parliament. The second area that I believe will be addressed fairly quickly is the outstanding matters relating to sanctions, compliance and a labour court. In broad terms that basically means: What happens to those who do not obey the rules, who do not accept the umpire's ruling?

The third area of concern to me, which has given rise to a private member's Bill that I have initiated, is the right to strike and the provisions of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. I believe that must be and will be addressed soon. The fourth broad area relates to compulsory versus voluntary unionism and the rights of individuals. The Australian Democrats have always opposed compulsory unionism. Therefore we look forward to the private member's Bill that the Hon. John Howard has indicated he will be initiating in the other place. They are the four broad areas of concern which we see as being addressed-and quite rightly-within three years or less.

This Bill addresses the first of those only-that is, the processes of amalgamation and restructuring. The Government has been dissatisfied with the pace of amalgamation and restructuring and sees these things as essential to the crucial changes which are long overdue in Australian industrial relations. The provisions of this Bill are designed to accelerate these processes. The Australian Democrats identify with this need and will, therefore, support the Bill in principle, although we will seek to amend it in some specific areas to which I will return shortly.

The Bill incorporates a range of amendments to the Act under seven broad headings and new objects of the Act will be demanded by the intention of the Bill. It addresses a fundamental area, the essence of the Bill, under the general heading of amalgamations and this raises the question: what should be the minimum size of a union? The Bill addresses the general powers of the Industrial Relations Commission and its involvement in this process of accelerating amalgamation and restructuring-which are specific powers which may change the structure of unions. It addresses critical and controversial areas of preference and it also addresses how we can secure observance of awards by employers, which gives rise to a number of technical changes. These are the broad headings contained within the Bill.

It is worth noting that an extraordinary degree of consensus has been reached, which probably emerged, we believe, as a consequence of five major reports which were put to the Parliament over a number of years and which have said certain things. Senator Durack has, quite appropriately, cited alternate statements which have been saying different things. But I think that in the five major reports which were cited by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in his second reading speech, we see the beginning of what has become a broad consensus in the community concerning the need for fewer unions. I do not think that Senator Durack will agree with me, but I believe that there is consensus that there should be a movement towards industry unions, and that process is occurring.

One of the main forums for this consensus-and this, I think, is to the credit of those who take part in this forum-is the National Labour Consultative Council (NLCC), comprising the Government, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the Confederation of Australian Industry, which come together periodically. In recent months there has been quite extraordinary consensus about the provisions of this Bill. In fact, the majority of the proposals within the Bill have the approval of the National Labour Consultative Council. The two broad areas of dispute which have been the most obvious ones within the NLCC have related to union size and to the question of preference.

I would like to congratulate the Minister, Senator Cook, on what he appears to be achieving and on the speed with which he appears to be achieving this through forums such as the NLCC. In my dealings with him-and I have consulted with him very closely on the provisions of this Bill-I have been impressed by his overview and far-sightedness in relation to the general area of industrial relations. I think he has a very clear view about what the Government intends to do and how it should achieve this, and I have found him to be very open-minded and certainly very articulate in enunciating that. I would like to cite a speech made by the Minister at the Australian Financial Review conference on 19 July 1990, and, indeed, I would like to quote from this document because I think it pulls together the Government's position in relation to this broad area of industrial relations.

The Minister had been asked to speak specifically on the relationship between the Government's policy and increased productivity within the Australian economy. I am quoting this document because I found it valuable in terms of bringing together my own focus regarding the broader aspects of government policy. In the Minister's introductory remarks he said that the essential thing we have to do is to create conditions where productivity can be improved within the Australian economy, and we have to do this quickly. I will quote three brief paragraphs from his speech. He stated:

This is the role of the industrial relations in improving productivity. Microeconomic reform will complement and facilitate microeconomic policy only if the industrial relations system sets out the environment for it and acts as its engine. This is a central point of the Government's policy. This policy has three inter-related levels: the overhaul of awards; rationalisation of the union structure; and retention of control over aggregate wage outcomes.
Quite obviously this Bill is addressing the second of those aspects quite specifically. The Minister continues:
The objective of each of them is (among other things) a more responsive and more flexible economy-and therefore a more productive and more efficient one.
I am prepared to accept that this Bill, in fact, meets those objectives. The Minister continues:

It has been accepted on all sides that our award structure has impeded microeconomic reform. It has herded employees into narrowly confined job paths and work patterns unsuited to modern machinery and modern times. It has complicated employers' dealings with employees and discouraged them from investing in training and other means towards using human resources more effectively. It has locked industry into old and (in many cases) obsolete forms of production.

Award restructuring is aimed at getting this burden off our backs. Its primary means is through the Structural Efficiency Principle (SEP), adopted by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in the last two National Wage Cases. There shouldn't be any need here to explain at greater length what SEP entails, except to underline the point that workers can't get access to wage improvements if they haven't participated in award restructuring aimed at improvements such as more flexible organisation of work.

What it is doing is pulling together the critical role of amalgamation and union restructuring with award restructuring, and relating that to economic outcomes of productivity. Frankly, I found that a very helpful statement and, therefore, I took a couple of minutes to draw it to the attention of honourable senators. Our role simply is to create an appropriate legislative framework within which industrial relations plays itself out. The internal dynamic of that process is not our business. Unions will squabble; there will be continued disruption; there will, in fact, be an attempt to preserve vested interests on the part of those who have belonged to smaller unions for years. That is the internal dynamic-it is separate from the legislative framework. It is our obligation to address that legislative framework.

The Australian Democrats have three broad areas of concern. Those areas of concern will become the focus of our subsequent amendments in the committee stage of the Bill. The first relates to union size and the need to strengthen exemption provisions; the second concerns participation processes; and the third relates to the rights of individuals within the legislative framework.

I would like to comment for a couple of moments on what is being proposed about structure and amalgamations. Traditionally, of course, there has been a horizontal structure within unions, and the general thrust and movement worldwide is to try and make those structures more vertical. The vertical structure seems to be appropriate and is being adopted in many countries. I make the observation-and it was made to me yesterday by the Association of Professional Engineers-that the vertical structure may be all very well, but once we start to talk about the involvement of professionally trained people, we probably need to impose upon that a lateral or horizontal structure which acknowledges the special role of professionals and scientifically and technically trained people which has to reach across a number of industries.

The Association draws attention to the Swedish model, and has presented its responses to, and arguments in favour of, that alternative structure in a document entitled, `Union Amalgamations-The Challenge for Professionals'. It is dated September 1990 and I commend it to honourable senators as being a statement of a very reasonable argument for a modified vertical structure.

Another general principle which we would enunciate is that we do support a strong Industrial Relations Commission in overseeing the process of amalgamation and restructuring. It is appropriate-as this Bill does-to strengthen the role and powers of the Industrial Relations Commission in relation to this process of accelerated amalgamations.

We do accept the need to set goals for numbers and times. The view of the Confederation of Australian Industry is that there is no need to prescribe numbers or time frames. We believe that there is value in setting a goal and setting a time frame within which those goals are to be achieved. We do not believe that they will be precisely achieved-in terms of either numbers or time-but there is value in setting the goals and the objectives. If they are not set there will not be the accelerated process which we regard as, and are convinced are, necessary.

We reject the ambit figure of 20,000 as being appropriate. We believe that from the very beginning it has been an ambit figure claimed by the Minister-probably on behalf of the ACTU. We think it has unfortunate and unnecessary connotations of mega-unions. We believe that the final outcome will be unions ranging from hundreds of thousands in strength down to a few hundred in strength, and that the precise figure really has no significance other than to act as a goal and to accelerate the process of amalgamation. We need not be preoccupied with it.

We will be moving an amendment to change the figure to 10,000, but only in very broad terms-it could be 9,000, it could be 11,000, it could be anything. We will be prescribing a time frame shorter than that prescribed within the Bill. In other words, in general terms, the Democrats are saying, `Sure, accelerate the process of amalgamation but don't create mega-unions en route-but we believe that it has to happen quickly'.

I foreshadow an amendment which I will move in the committee stage for a reduction of the ambit figure from 20,000 to 10,000, and a reduction of the time frame from March 1995 to possibly March 1992 or 1993. We will deliberate about which is the most appropriate of those two dates between now and the committee stage, which is some time off, I understand.

One of the most important aspects of this process, as far as we are concerned, is to strengthen the exemption provisions. Within the present Act there is provision for small unions to argue special circumstances and say, `Look, we have walked the course of amalgamation; it was a bad experience; we don't want to be forced back there again; it does not make any sense for all sorts of reasons'. As I say, within the present Act there is provision to argue special circumstances.

We believe that the Act as it now stands, however, is suggestively coercive and does suggest to the Commission a pressure to amalgamate. We will be seeking a rewording of the Act through an amendment which will more clearly communicate to the Commission and to the court that coercion is not the aim of the game. To put it in blunt terms, we are not in favour of shotgun weddings and we believe that, in the final analysis, if union members do not support the process of amalgamation, it should not proceed. We believe that that spirit is brought out in the newly stated objectives of the Act, which emphasise the importance of participation in the process of amalgamation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you think there are some provisions in this Bill which will make it more difficult for individuals?

—I will move on to that aspect of participation in a minute. We believe that this more adequately accommodates the need dictated by the International Labour Organisation (ILO) covenant, signed by Australia, which supports freedom of association. We believe that the strengthening of the exemption provisions will more appropriately comply with the ILO covenant. Senator Durack asks are we not frightened by the aspects of the Bill which amend the processes of participation? Initially, on first examination, we were. We have looked at those provisions in detail and are now convinced that they will not reduce the process or threaten the processes of participation.

SPEECH.PARA: The three things that are suggested within the Bill will happen under certain circumstances, and these circumstances must always be approved by the Commission and must always be overseen by the Electoral Commission, which are in themselves two very strong provisos. Provided the Industrial Relations Commission is convinced that participation and democracy are preserved, it will exempt ballots under some circumstances, such as those ballots for the marriage of larger components. The Commission will also allow the processes to occur through secret ballots at mass meetings rather than necessarily through secret postal ballots.

I have sought clarification on the arguments that have come to me. I find those arguments convincing, and our Party finds them convincing. We do not believe that participation in democracy is threatened by the exemption provisions of the Bill. I will give more attention to that point obviously in the committee stage of the debate.

The final broad area of concern to the Democrats-and this is a very challenging one-is the rights of individuals. We believe that there is an inherent danger still within the Act not adequately addressed by the provisions of the Bill. The inherent danger is that individuals can find themselves disadvantaged because the essential rationale of the Act and the Bill is a focus on organisations and collectives. We believe there has to be a strengthening of the protection of individual rights.

I will cite, but not name, a case that is currently before the State Industrial Relations Commission in New South Wales, where an individual by law does not have access to the Commission unless it is by special writ of the Minister. In the case of this individual now before the Commission, I obtained that special writ from the State Minister. This individual, an unemployed person, on the dole, now finds himself standing before the Commission without legal aid and arguing his case against QCs, not even able to cover the cost of photocopying the transcript of proceedings from the previous day unless he pays $2 a page. Therefore, he has to stand and, by hand, transcribe from court records and proceedings. That person does not have equal rights before that court. We believe that there are in the present Act inherent dangers which are not sufficiently addressed by the Bill. In essence, the Democrats support in principle the thrust of the Bill. In the committee stage we will seek to rectify the inadequacies I have cited. We commend the general intention of the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator McLean on an excellent and well-considered speech. When we are in the committee stage, I will listen to him, either here or in my room. I congratulate Senator Durack too, because in opposing the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill he illustrated the Opposition's Achilles heel in this area-that members of the Opposition have an unease with unions and the ordinary working person. They feel that unless great restraint is placed upon workers they will somehow move into revolt and bring the country to ruin. If that is their attitude to workers, it is even more so their attitude to unions. Senator Durack used the hoary old chestnut of the left wing unions going forward to ruin the country.
—Are they disappearing?

—That was the expression Senator Durack used. It indicates that the old ways have persisted despite the union movement's splendid record over the last decade and despite the fact that there have been considerable changes in eastern Europe and a rapprochement between East and West. In spite of those very significant changes in the climate in which we live, there are still people and organisations-and the Opposition is one-that talk about left wing imperialism, left wing dissent and left wing corruption, and say that these things will be typified by the amalgamation of unions. The record is against that. Under this Government the culture, aspirations and mood of Australia's industrial relations have changed dramatically. In a little while I want to make some key points about that from the economic data.

SPEECH.PARA: The adversarial relationship that existed between worker and management before March 1983 has been transformed into a much more cooperative one. More and more, all levels of industry are coming to understand the need for consensus in the workplace. This is essential not only for the economic health of the nation but also for its democratic ethos. I want to stress this because it has not been stressed enough. During the last decade the approach taken by this Government to industrial change has done much for the Australian way of life. The approach should be seen not simply in terms of industrial policy or economic policy but also in terms of the political fabric of this society, the sorts of values we have and the culture that we live in.

Great reform has taken place in society without violence to the tenets of a free community. This is an achievement that deserves high praise. During the 1980s dramatic shifts occurred in the workplace practices of other countries. I think that matter has already been dealt with this morning by both Senator Durack and Senator McLean.

The sacking of the air traffic controllers in the United States at the beginning of the decade signalled the harsh social changes which have occurred there. During the same period, industrial reform was carried out in the United Kingdom with much bitterness between workers, employers and government. There has been a lot of change in industrial relations in both the United Kingdom and the United States over the last 10 years. In both cases the style of that change, the method of it, has left a lot of bitterness. The sorts of riots that we have seen in the United Kingdom, and that have been dramatically demonstrated on the television screen, have not happened in Australia. The sorts of violence, poverty and degradation that have occurred amongst the have-nots in the United States have not happened here. The two nations that Benjamin Disraeli spoke about, both the United Kingdom and the United States, have grown during the 1980s but that has not happened here.

One of the great achievements for this Government will be to bring about the change that is needed, but to do it via preserving the very fabric of democracy. Democracy is not simply a matter of having the ability to cast a vote every three years. It is also a matter of having as many people as possible take part in the process of change and having those people take part not on the basis of confrontation but on the basis of cooperation.

The economic and industrial policies pursued by the Government over the life of the four Parliaments that it has now controlled has established in Australia the sort of ethos, culture and political approach that is an example for the rest of the world. I think that this Government has reason to be very proud because of that. The course that the Government has pursued has enhanced the character of this nation as a free and cohesive society.

I now turn to the key points of the economic data. These figures have been quoted again and again in this chamber in many debates over the last few years. They are worth repeating in the context of talking about the next step in the process of making this country even better than it presently is. The consumer price index increase was 1.6 per cent in the June quarter of this year compared to 11.5 per cent over the last years of the Fraser Government.

I do not want to go into the exercise of saying that the present problems in Australia date back to the Fraser years, although there is much merit in that proposition. I simply want to illustrate at this point in the argument that the economic indicators that this Government can quote are much better than those that the Opposition could quote when it was last in Government. Average weekly earnings are up 6.7 per cent over the year to May 1990. The real unit labour costs, on the other hand, were down 12.8 per cent between March 1983 and March 1990. Productivity is up 4 per cent in the non-farm market sector and 3.8 per cent in manufacturing in the period 1988-89.

Employment is up 1.68 million under Labor. Again, I do not duck the problem that still exists in the increase in the number of people who are unemployed. Anybody who is unemployed deserves the sympathy of us all. Under its policies this Government has produced a remarkable number of jobs. The rate of unemployment under it is well down on what was the position when it came to government in March 1983. At that time it was 10.1 per cent.

Also, the level of industrial disputes-this is the last figure I will quote-is down 60 per cent under the Australian Labor Party on the level of the Fraser years. When this Government brings legislation into the chamber and asks Parliament to accept and pass it, it does so in the context of its remarkable record, not only in terms of industrial relations or economic policy but also in terms of the way of life that we now enjoy, the democratic processes that it has enhanced and the cohesive society that it has produced.

This Government can come to the Parliament with confidence and say that on the record it has established the Parliament ought to give very solid consideration to passing this legislation. The Australian Democrats have accepted that and have said, `Yes, we have looked at this legislation and, subject to some amendments we want to make which we will pursue at the committee stage, we agree with the general thrust of what the Government has done'. I suppose part of the Opposition's approach is to oppose-that is what it is here for-but we hope that in opposing the legislation it will do so constructively rather than simply saying, `This is a left wing plot; this Government is the captive of the Australian Council of Trade Unions; it is all dreadful and therefore we will throw it out'.

Why not look at the legislation and see what it does? In that context it might be worth while going to the Bill itself. Much of this has been pointed out already, but it starts off, in clause 4, by stating quite candidly what it is about. It says that it is going to amend the principal Act by adding to the objectives the following:
(j) to encourage and facilitate the amalgamation of organisations; and
(k) to encourage and facilitate the development of organisations, particularly by reducing the number of organisations that are in an industry or enterprise.
That is what the Bill is about. It wants amalgamation because the evidence is that amalgamation is what is best not only for the union movement but also for the nation as a whole.

Amalgamation is not some new process that is going to take place under this amended Act. There have been amalgamations under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act for a long time. In 1975 the Federated Artificial Fertiliser and Chemical Workers unions amalgamated and continued under the name of the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia. The world did not collapse when that happened.

In 1976 the Australian Workers Union and the Wool and Basil Workers Federation of Australia amalgamated. The interesting thing is that in 1979 the Graziers Association of Victoria and the Victorian Farmers Union Employers Association amalgamated under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to join the Victorian Farmers Federation Industrial Association.

In 1982 the Tasmanian Farmers Federation employers association and the Tasmanian Farmers, Stockowners and Orchardists Association amalgamated to form the Tasmanian Farmers and Growers Industrial Association. Those are employer organisations, which indicates that employer organisations understand the need to amalgamate and the need, as society changes and we get closer and closer to the twenty-first century, for amalgamation and reform, and undertake it in that context.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Loosley, along with many other Australians, will have seen an article in the Australian today by Tracey Aubin.
—A good article, too.

—There are few articles that are good that quote Senator Boswell, especially on this issue. This article is no exception to that general rule of thumb. ANSWER.PARA: Essentially, two issues are involved. The first is the question of the Medicare card and its use by the Health Insurance Commission to check pharmaceutical benefits scheme eligibility. TALK.START.PARA: —Backdoor introduction of the Australia Card.

That checking is already being done at the moment, by the way; it is not new.

—Senator Boswell should listen; there are many things that he ought to listen to. There is no proposal to do anything other than to continue by computer what is being done, manually, right now. Manually, right now, my Department checks these same pieces of information. Obviously, given the millions of people involved, it is a very slow, inefficient and costly process. That is not in anyone's best interests. Records-the tapes-from the Tax Office will be taken by hand to my Department for matching in our computers. There is no possibility at any time that the thousands of people--
—Rubbish!

—It is not rubbish. Senator Patterson would not know. There is no possibility that on the thousands of computer screens operated by my Department around the country any person in my Department would be able to tap into that computer and get results from Tax. It is impossible for that to happen-and we would not allow it to happen. Were it to happen, I would be against it. Because there is no linkage--

ANSWER.PARA: The article in today's Australian again mentioned the Privacy Commission. The article contained an extraordinary piece of selective quoting.
