ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister's remarks may well have been made in 1987, as Senator Powell said. They reflect views he has expressed recently, to the effect that the Government will not sell Telecom. The Prime Minister's figures to which Senator Powell referred were authoritatively based, being sourced from the telecommunications authorities of the relevant countries or from the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. It is no good Senator Powell coming in here and saying this happened in the United Kingdom or something else happened in the United States of America at a particular time and prices may have gone up or may have gone down and therefore one can draw conclusions about the principles which the honourable senator sought to enunciate, I suppose, in a fairly obscure way, in the substance of her question.

The Government's view is that effective competition will lead to reductions in prices. It is not only competition that will lead to reductions in prices, but also technological change. The Government has made it clear that, in its view, telephone prices will fall. The other issue is whether services provided by Telecom and a range of value-added industries also will fall. The anticipation can be that they will. I might add that the appropriate safeguards to which the Government has referred in recent days will protect the position of disadvantaged groups. I refer particularly to the community service obligations of Telecom, which are not to be confused with the commercial obligations of the Commonwealth Bank, as they were yesterday by Senator Powell's colleague Senator Spindler.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask my question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. When the Government laid down the present television ownership rules it admitted that might mean there would be one less television network. Do Mr Beazley's statements last night indicate that the Government is now committed fully to a three private network system? Further, the Government will be aware of press reports which indicate that potential buyers for channel 10 may envisage a restricted programming service. Will the Minister assure the Senate that any changes in the ownership of channel 10 will result in the maintenance of a fully operational independent network?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not challenge in any sense Senator Kemp's view, but I do not recall the Government's saying in 1987 or whenever it was that the new television ownership rules would lead possibly to a reduction in the number of networks. If the honourable senator says that was said, I accept that it may be so. On this issue the Minister for Transport and Communications last night made the Government's position fairly clear: first, that the policy objectives underlying the current broadcasting legislation should continue to be observed; second, that these policy objectives include an adequate and comprehensive service and limits on cross-ownership of television stations; and, third, that the Broadcasting Tribunal has the job of implementing these policies. More importantly, Mr Beazley last night made it clear that the Government will back the decisions of the Tribunal. If it proves necessary, this backing will include appropriate amendments to legislation effective from last night.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Kemp then went on to ask me to speculate about some circumstances which might arise if certain things happen in the marketplace. All I can say about that is that, having set the principles, as Mr Beazley did last night, it is not appropriate for me to act on any supposition, rumour or scuttlebutt about what might happen in board meetings today or in certain other circumstances which might affect the television industry. However, I repeat that, in terms of the policy, the Government will act if the facts justify it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of reports from Myanmar that the State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC) Government has recently arrested more senior leaders of the National League for Democracy (NLD)? Can the Minister confirm these reports and, if they are correct, what action has the Government taken to protest at this further abuse of human rights in Myanmar? Furthermore, can the Minister give an indication of whether the Australian Government will seek international cooperation in applying further strenuous diplomatic pressure on the SLORC Government for it to transfer power to the democratically elected National Assembly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The situation in Myanmar is certainly increasingly tense and unhappy. The military regime has shown by its actions that it is unwilling to consider seriously a transfer of power to the representatives elected in the national elections on 27 May. The ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council-or SLORC, as Senator Schacht said-is continuing to rely on repression and intimidation. On 7 September, in what can only be described as a pre-emptive clampdown against the country's major political party, the National League for Democracy, the spokesman and acting leader of the NLD, Kyi Maung, and four other leaders of the party were taken into detention in the early hours of the morning. I condemned that action in a formal statement that was issued in very strong terms later that day. On 8 August, a little earlier, in Mandalay, police, for the first time in over a year, used force to put down a demonstration, killing six or seven demonstrators-most of them monks and students. Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of the NLD, is still being held under house arrest, well over a year after she was first detained, and no indication has been given as to when she might be released.

ANSWER.PARA: Since the elections, there have been further widespread arrests of political activists, most of them associated with the NLD. The SLORC, very regrettably, has made it clear that it does not see the May elections as leading to genuine democratic change. From its public statements, it is evidently expecting that the representatives elected so overwhelmingly in May will simply be charged with drawing up a new constitution. This would then have to be approved by the SLORC and perhaps put to a referendum prior to a further election from which a government might then be formed. Such a process could take well over a year, if not much longer, and would deny the clear wish of the majority of the population for meaningful democratic reform within a reasonable timeframe. However, to date, the SLORC has set no date even for the convening of an assembly for the limited purpose of drafting a new constitution.

For its part, the NLD, which honourable senators will recall won 392 out of the 485 seats contested in May, is clearly becoming increasingly, and increasingly justifiably, impatient. At the end of a delegates' conference on 30 July, the NLD called for a convening of a national assembly with full legislative powers by the end of September. It is that action that has now created the tension and uncertainty in the situation to which I referred.

As to Australia's response to all of this, I will quickly detail it. Shortly after the election results were announced, I wrote to senior General Saw Maung, Chairman of the SLORC and Myanmar Foreign Minister, urging that there should be a prompt transfer of power to democratic government. At my request, our ambassador asked the authorities if he could call on Aung San Suu Kyi to deliver a message of support. That request was refused. However, I also wrote to the Acting Chairman of the NLD to congratulate the party on its success in the elections. I have informed other interested governments of the actions taken by Australia and we have been encouraging them to take similar action to support a transition to democracy in Myanmar.

In early July, I indicated that I would not review the suspension of the Australian aid program to Myanmar unless there was a transfer of power to a democratic government. Later in July we called formally for the release of Aung San Suu Kyi and expressed the Government's profound disappointment at the decision of the military regime to extend her detention; and, of course, I repeat that again today. I hope that when I go to New York shortly for the United Nations General Assembly meeting, I will be able to meet again with the leader of the Myanmar delegation to discuss the situation in Myanmar and to further communicate our concerns about the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Should there be trade sanctions?

—That is a matter of judgment, Senator. The utility of trade sanctions has to be measured, among other things, by the extent of international support for them. It can be an empty, quixotic and counterproductive gesture unless there is a broader base of support. No doubt that is something the international community will have to shortly turn its mind to.

ANSWER.PARA: On the matter of international cooperation generally, which was the last part of Senator Schacht's question, I simply want to say that Australia has maintained close contact with other countries similarly concerned over the situation in Myanmar with the aim of taking joint action whenever that is possible. We have been regularly associated with joint diplomatic demarches in Yangon in which the United States and European Community countries have also been prominent. I raised the situation in Myanmar with my Association of South East Asian Nations ministerial colleagues at the ASEAN post-ministerial meeting in July. I will be exploring with likeminded countries the possibility of taking further measures at the forthcoming General Assembly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Was the Prime Minister, along with leaders of most other nations of the world, invited to attend the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) summit in New York over the weekend of 29 and 30 September which is to focus on universal problems facing children in the 1990s? Is it also a fact that the Prime Minister refused this invitation saying that he had other commitments? Is it a fact that the UNICEF goodwill ambassador, Sir Peter Ustinov, has been very critical of the Prime Minister, pointing out that if Presidents Bush, Mitterrand and Prime Ministers Thatcher and Mulroney, and possibly President Gorbachev, could find the time to attend, it should be good enough for Mr Hawke to attend? Has Sir Peter also been critical in pointing out that by sending Senator Gareth Evans to represent our Head of State, Australia would have observer status only? Finally, now that the VFL grand final which was falling on the same weekend has been delayed a week, will the Prime Minister change his mind and carry out his responsibilities to Australia by attending this important conference?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Prime Minister was invited to attend the UNICEF summit. The Government certainly welcomes that summit and supports it because it focuses on the needs of children.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has other commitments, as the interjectors have already pointed out, at the national conference of the Australian Labor Party. The Prime Minister has written to the host, Prime Minister Mulroney, or one of the organisers of the summit, explaining that he is unable to attend and that he will be represented by Senator Gareth Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. As I understand it, Senator Evans will be endorsing the declaration on behalf of Australia and his presence records the high priority that the Government accords to the summit and our commitment to the needs of all children.

ANSWER.PARA: As to Peter Ustinov's criticising the Prime Minister, I am sure that it has been done in a much more gentlemanly way than it is often done in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the Government's workplace reform program, which was established to facilitate its policies of encouraging award restructuring and workplace reform. I ask if this intrinsic part of the Government's economic reform strategy is working successfully, particularly as part of the Government's intention to facilitate award restructuring at the enterprise level?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has embarked on a program to underpin the very good work that has been done, based on the accord submissions to the Industrial Relations Commission over the last several years encouraging award restructuring. This will ensure that the fruits of award restructuring are reflected in better arrangements in the workplace. That program is, as Senator McKiernan has said, the workplace reform program.

ANSWER.PARA: I should say, as someone associated with industrial relations for a long time until 1983 and coming back to it just this year, that I am astonished by the amount of change that has occurred in rationalising the award structures in Australia and some of the shibboleths that have been broken down over that period in order to broad-band award structures and make their format more flexible. I commend the union movement, employers and the Industrial Relations Commission for responding to the accord-based submissions that have enabled that to occur. The next challenge is to translate those gains, which are reflected in the way in which the awards are written, into real life practices in the workplace. To do that requires a continuation of the revolution, starting with award restructuring. It requires two parties to be involved.

The Business Council of Australia has funded a survey conducted by Monash University of examples of what is, in fact, going on in workplace reform. The survey found, inter alia, that the biggest obstruction to achieving genuine reform in the workplace is conservatism by employers in embracing the opportunities that the restructured awards provide. There is a serious obligation on employers to actually look creatively at the changes that have occurred in award restructuring and apply them to the workplace, in consort with the unions in that workplace, to achieve better flexibility and more efficient processes and generate greater productivity.

One of the things that is part of accord mark 6 is direct bargaining in the workplace to share the achieved productivity and profitability goals. There is a willingness, I think, on the side of the union movement; there is a willingness at peak level in employer bodies; and there is a reluctance to embrace the opportunity in the workplace by particular employers. Our program is aimed at motivating change in that area. We fund work change agents to work with employer groups and unions to do so. I think, with the impetus that we are able to put behind that program, that we might well be able to encourage significant change in the workplace for the benefit of the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport to the revised recommendations of the Inter-State Commission with respect to vehicle registrations, in which the proposed road use charges for road trains will be in the vicinity of $42,000. Is the Minister concerned that this constitutes an increase in road use charges of approximately 700 per cent with a 350 per cent increase in the first year? Can the Minister advise how many transport operators the Government expects will go out of business as a result of these proposals and can he justify how the Government expects this enormous increase in costs to be borne by remote and rural Australia when incomes in these areas are going to fall 50 per cent this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope I do not do Senator O'Chee an injustice if I say that I hope, by inference, that his question does not indicate that the coalition has the same hypocritical approach to this issue as it has to the issue of accountability in the social security services that are provided in this country. Recently, at the Australian Transport Advisory Council, I listened very carefully to the debate on this very subject. I was interested in the unanimity of opinion among the Labor and conservative State leaders at that conference, with caveats put on by the Labor governments of South Australia and, I think, Queensland; certainly the conservative Government of New South Wales; and the Northern Territory, which also put on a caveat. They all agreed in principle on the fundamental thrust of this, I must say, overdue reform.

ANSWER.PARA: What this Federal Government is trying to do-and, I believe, it will succeed-is get some sort of rational national transportation system established in this country for the first time since we federated as a nation. It is long overdue. We are currently faced with the ridiculous situation in the rail and road area of having widely differing regulations applying to the transportation systems from State to State. The widely differing registration charges that apply from State to State put State governments-conservative and Labor-in a very difficult position because, when they try to be responsible and introduce road charges which equate, for example, with the cost of maintenance required to repair the damage caused by the transportation of freight, they are frustrated by the simple expedient of truck companies not moving to States physically, but setting up companies in States where the registration charges are massively lower and simply continuing to operate from State to State.

If I might make a plea for the conservative Government of New South Wales-and Senator O'Chee might like to direct his attention to the problems faced by his conservative colleagues there- one of the difficulties it faces is that New South Wales is an interstate route. It is a big problem when one thinks about it: an enormous amount of traffic from Victoria to Queensland, and vice versa, passes along the road systems of New South Wales. That is just one small example, in a very complex issue, of the problems that the Government is attempting to alleviate, with-I must say-an enormous amount of cooperation from State governments now.

The principle involved is that there be some sort of national road system introduced. It is inevitable that in trying to set up such a system anomalies will occur. That is the nature of this country and of the particular kind of constitutional set-up we have: State and Federal governments, with the enormous distances and our highly urbanised population. I have said in this chamber before that we have one of the most difficult transportation and communication tasks of any nation on earth.

There are anomalies. Some of the obvious ones have been raised by Senator O'Chee. Everyone agrees, conservative and Labor, that the principle is worth pursuing, but there are certain areas of Australia where particular modes of transport are used which are not used anywhere else in the country. In particular, I refer to road trains in the Northern Territory, massive vehicles, commonplace to us, more than 100 feet in length, which are in regular use on our roads. They operate economically but cannot be used anywhere else in the country because of the nature of the highway systems and the congestion of traffic elsewhere.

What has happened in respect of those vehicles is that the Inter-State Commission has taken on board the concerns of truck companies in those situations. On behalf of my constituents affected by this problem I have personally made representations to Mr Butcher. The Inter-State Commission complied with its undertaking that an investigation would be carried out into these anomalies. Further recommendations dealing with this issue raised by Senator O'Chee have been provided to the Government and it is currently in the position of considering those further recommendations of Mr Butcher from the Inter-State Commission. The Government will be in a position shortly-I hope before the end of the year-to make a statement on its final position regarding the Inter-State Commission's recommendations in this important matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. Like Senator Collins, we have all been making representations over the enormous impact this will have on the road transport industry, but it does not seem to be doing much good. I direct Senator Collins again to the question of the enormous increase in costs, of up to 700 per cent. It is a cost borne not just by road train operators but also by semitrailer operators, and when the Federal Government receives over $6 billion a year in fuel excise and returns a little over $1 billion to the road network, how does Senator Collins justify these enormous increases in charges?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is simply a repeat of the question I have already tried to answer but I will answer it again for Senator O'Chee. We have a country the size of the United States of America, with a population the size of the city of Los Angeles; we have an area of 3 million square miles-and I am afraid I still think in square miles-with most of our population concentrated in two cities and the rest of us spread across the country and there are enormous distances to be covered by quality road services. How we pay for and maintain it is a huge problem. Frankly, as someone who has used those roads for most of my life-that is, in the outback-considering the problems involved in crossing those huge distances with small populations, I am amazed that we have a road system of the quality that we have in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: I will give an indication of the kinds of difficulties that I am talking about. Between the southern border of the Northern Territory and Darwin are the towns of Alice Springs, with 20,000 people, Tennant Creek, with 3,000 people, and Katherine, with 5,000 people. Then there is the Big Apple at the end of the highway, Darwin, with a population of 65,000. To join those cities, comprising a total population of about 100,000 people, requires 2,000 kilometres of very high quality road indeed. That is one indication of the kinds of problems I am talking about. That road system has to be paid for.

I am pleased that in the last couple of years the spotlight has finally been put by this Government on that very problem of how we develop a brand new approach to rationally paying for those roads. In conclusion, I ask Senator O'Chee to consult his conservative colleagues in State parliaments. He should have a talk to them because they are joined with this Government in the pursuit of this goal.

TALK.START.PARA: — Does the Minister for Industrial Relations recall the commitment by the Prime Minister earlier this year that the Government would set up a specialist unit within the Department of Industrial Relations to monitor and advise the Government on pay equity issues? Can the Minister advise the Senate on progress made in setting up this unit, which will focus on the gap between female and male pay rates and, hopefully, bring about some changes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I can advise the Senate. The Senate should, like others in Australia, consider that, according to the average weekly ordinary times earning index, if the rate of full adult male earnings is 100 per cent, the full adult female earnings rate is 83 per cent. If the index is calculated on overtime, females earn 78 per cent of male earnings.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason for that disparity is not that this Government has not supported equal pay. The first equal pay for equal work decision was made in 1968; the second equal pay for work of equal value decision was made in 1972; in 1974 the Whitlam Government supported changes to enable minimum rates of pay to be extended to females on the same basis as they have been extended to males. The reason is that there is a considerable amount of gender discrimination in the work force, notwithstanding those decisions, and there are a whole host of jobs which traditionally or typically are low paid and regarded as `women's work'-type jobs.

Despite our enlightenment and attention to equal opportunity, it is not surprising these days to still walk into an office in the central business district of any city and see an office full of women doing all the menial work, with a male supervisor. They may not have promotional opportunities because traditionally it is simply the view of some employers that women ought not to be promoted to those areas of responsibility. It is also the case that where women are clustered in low paid jobs those low paid jobs are deliberately undervalued in terms of their true worth in comparison with male jobs.

In recognition of those problems the Government concluded in February with the ACTU an accord mark 6-a commitment to establish in the Pay and Equity Division of the Department of Industrial Relations an equal pay unit. The Government announced the funding of that unit in the Budget. The purpose of the unit is to take part in wage cases to try to overcome these difficulties, to encourage in the award restructuring program and in the workplace reform program steps to overcome that process and to provide a basis of advocacy in cases more generally before the Industrial Relations Commission to address the issues of pay inequity that so bedevil the work force. The unit, which is now having staff recruited to it, will be in action shortly and will be an important supplement to the Government's efforts to ensure equity in the wages system in Australia.

I conclude by saying that yesterday the Government referred to pay inequity issues in the body of its general submission to the national wage case. For the interest of the Senate I table the Government's submission to the national wage case yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Having today received an Australian Science and Technology Council report entitled Setting Directions for Australian Research hotly on the tail of another ASTEC report, Science, Technology and Australia's Future, and looking on my shelves at the rows of reports into every possible aspect of scientific education, management and research which have accumulated over the past decade and which altogether have produced a decline in government participation and funding over that period, I ask the Minister: what is expected to be achieved by the White Paper that this latest report is now proposing? Is it expected that such a move would increase government involvement or is it likely to be just another delay in getting some real action and commitment?
—A shillyshally question!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Archer's question has been made more colourful by Senator Patterson's interjection, which described it as a shillyshally. I am delighted to know that Senator Archer collects all those reports. He is probably the only person in the Parliament who does and probably the only person in the Commonwealth who does. They are available for every interested senator or member of the Parliament to refer to whenever they want to, but I am sure there are as not as many enthusiastic collectors about as Senator Archer.

ANSWER.PARA: The gravamen of Senator Archer's question was his allegation that government funding on research has declined. I do not know how often we have to have this debate with the honourable senator. I do not think government funding on research has declined significantly. The important point is that government funding on research has declined relative to the contribution of the private sector, which in the Opposition's seven years of government in the 1970s was at the worst level in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development.

Members of the Opposition come in here from time to time wanting to debate issues with us about privatisation and competition. I find it strange that Senator Archer comes in here raising questions and arguments which suggest by implication that the role of research funding is exclusively a government role. It is not exclusively a government role.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said nothing of the sort.

—That is the premise of the honourable senator's question: `Having regard to the fact that government funding of research has declined, what is the White Paper going to do?'. I do not whether Senator Archer wrote that question himself, but let me tell him what it means.
—Don't be offensive.

—I am sure he wrote it himself; he knows more about this than the rest of the Opposition put together. But that does not say very much. The premise of his question is simply that government research funding has declined; therefore a White Paper cannot contribute anything to the future of research in this country. That is the premise of the question. The premise of the Government's position is simply that we had to improve private sector research performance in this country, and we have done that.

ANSWER.PARA: The total level of research funding in this country has increased very significantly during the period of this Government. That is something that the Opposition was unable to achieve when it was in government and something which we set out to redress. And we have done it-not as satisfactorily as we might wish, but the fact is that there has been an enormous change in the contribution of the private sector to research.

I cannot answer Senator Archer's question about what the White Paper will do because I have not had the advantage of seeing it and nor has he. But maybe it will pull all those reports that are on Senator Archer's shelf together so that he can get rid of the early volumes and have one volume which pools all the wisdom in those reports and lays down directions for further research activity in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Besides ASTEC which produced this report, in recent times we have added the Prime Minister's Science Council, the Coordination Committee on Science and Technology and the Office of the Chief Scientist. I believe that Senator Button has a chief science adviser as well. What is the purpose of these bodies, with all the eminent scientists that they embrace, if between them they are unable to advise the Government on the action that is necessary?

—The purpose of these bodies-particularly the Prime Minister's Science Council-is raising the profile of scientific industries and scientific endeavour in this country from the abysmally low level of the 1970s. Senator Archer asked about the purpose of these bodies. Most European governments have a national science council, as does the United States of America. I suppose that Senator Archer would say that ASTEC performs that sort of function. Well, perhaps it does in part, but the point of these bodies is that they are designed to raise the profile of science in Australia and Senator Archer knows full well that that is a very necessary thing to do because the profile of science education in Australia is low. He knows that the awareness of science in the Australian community is low. That is what those bodies are for. I would have thought that Senator Archer would support that rather than denigrate it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General-and I believe that today it will be Senator Evans. Is the Minister aware that some basic human rights which are explicitly listed in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR), and to which Australia claims to be committed, are denied to some residents in New South Wales? Is he aware that in New South Wales employees are not recognised as persons in their own right before the industrial jurisdiction and that if they gain access to the court by specific ministerial writ they are then excluded from legal aid in that jurisdiction, even if they may meet all other requirements-for instance, being on the dole? Can the Minister advise when Australia will sign and ratify the optional protocol to the ICCPR which will allow the United Nations Human Rights Committee to consider communications from individual Australians? Finally, can he advise when the Government will communicate Australia's declaration under article 41 of the ICCPR to the United Nations, recognising the competence of the United Nations Human Rights Committee on questions of human rights in bilateral State-party issues in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the first two parts of the question-although these matters of State legislation are properly matters for consideration by the appropriate State authorities-I am able to say nonetheless that the procedural matters to which Senator McLean refers provided for in the New South Wales Industrial Arbitration Act do not, in our judgment, contravene a requirement in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights that all persons are to be equal before the courts and tribunals.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the legal aid aspects of his question, I am informed that as individuals are not parties to industrial proceedings, legal aid is not normally made available to them.

As to Senator McLean's third question, the Attorney-General is actively pursuing the matter of the first optional protocol with his State and Territory counterparts in the forum of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. The decision on signatory ratification has to await the outcome of the process of consultation. I simply hope and expect that that action will not be much longer delayed.

The declaration under article 41 of the covenant to which he finally referred is of course related to that issue of the first optional protocol. The Government believes that the key step is to achieve accession to the first optional protocol. The Government is therefore concentrating its efforts on achieving that accession and will then put its efforts to the article 41 declaration and other related matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I understand the Minister to be saying that the State legislation does not contravene the requirements of the international covenant and yet, would not the Minister agree, individuals have no access to a court of New South Wales unless it is by the grace of the Minister. Would he not agree that when they get there they are disadvantaged if they do not have legal aid, if they are employed, for instance, and is it not a fact that the Federal Attorney-General has formally advised the United Nations that all Australians have equal standing before all courts of this country?

—I do not have much further information with which I can respond more specifically than I have. It is my understanding that the nature of the proceedings in question in the New South Wales Industrial Commission relate to the fixing of hours, rates of pay and so on and proceedings in those matters, and appropriately one would think they would be commenced not by individuals but by parties to industrial matters-namely, employers and representatives of employees, the trade unions.

ANSWER.PARA: The procedure of the Act requires such a proceeding to be commenced by an application and a prescribed form to be signed by an employer or a union. There is also provision for reference of such matters by the relevant Minister or by the Commission itself. I think it is really stretching a long bow to argue that these relatively familiar industrial proceedings in specialist tribunals somehow call into question the applicability of fundamental human rights standards. I am not saying human rights standards have no application in industrial matters, although that is an argument that I suppose could be run-that the area of litigation is sui juris and not related to individual rights and issues of that kind.

I think I have said enough to make it apparent that there is a reasonable prima facie response to what Senator McLean is saying. If he wants to take it up any further, he can take it up with the New South Wales Government and leave us alone.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Tuesday Senator Lewis asked me a question relating to trade practices legislation. I said I would seek further information about it. I have that information from the Attorney-General. The Trade Practices Commission decided not to take legal action against Toshiba Australia in respect of alleged resale price maintenance in computer hardware in exchange for a formal undertaking by the company to set up long term compliance training for its staff. The training program covers executives, staff and agents, and is to be conducted over three years. The Chairman of the Commission is reported as saying that this resulted in a better market result than would have been obtained from costly and protracted litigation.

ANSWER.PARA: The case illustrates that there are times when actions other than court actions may lead to a more satisfactory outcome, and it highlights the need in all areas of the law to look closely at alternative ways of resolving disputes.

With regard to the level of penalties for infringements of the restrictive trade practice provisions, which was another part of the honourable senator's question, I mention that the Act provides for a pecuniary penalty of up to $250,000 for each offence of a corporation. There have been suggestions that this penalty needs to be increased, and the Government is looking at those suggestions at present.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 August Senator Short asked me a question, in my capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer, relating to the State Bank of South Australia and the State Bank of Victoria. The Treasurer has provided information. The Reserve Bank informed the Treasurer that in December 1989 the State Bank of Victoria issued $300m worth of floating rate stock which qualified as capital for the purposes of the Reserve Bank's capital adequacy guidelines. This was the fourth issue by the State Bank of Victoria of debt which qualified for inclusion as capital.

ANSWER.PARA: The normal practice when a bank wishes to raise debt capital is that prior to making the issue it discusses terms and conditions with the Reserve Bank to ensure that the proposed issue will meet the Reserve Bank tests for inclusion as capital. State Banks follow this practice also. The Reserve Bank does not have any contact with Commonwealth Ministers about proposed issues of capital instruments. These processes were followed in relation to the State Bank of Victoria issue. The Reserve Bank did not approve, nor was it aware of subscribers to the State Bank of Victoria's debt capital issue. The Bank does not normally seek such information. The answer read as follows-

Senator Harradine asked me, on 11 September 1990, a question without notice on the causes of the current level of unemployment including hidden unemployment. I undertook to provide further information on that part of the question dealing with hidden unemployment.
I can now advise the Senate that:
* The best available information on hidden unemployment is the ABS estimate of discouraged jobseekers.

* The primary difference between discouraged jobseekers and the unemployed is that the former are not actively seeking work because they believe they would not find a job for one or more of the following reasons:
- they were considered too young or too old by employers;
- difficulties with language or ethnic background;
- they lacked the necessary schooling, training, skills or experience; or
- there were no jobs in their locality or line of work.
* The most recent discouraged worker figures are for September 1989, when ABS estimated that there were 76,100 hidden unemployed in Australia.
* This Government has addressed the problems of hidden unemployment in several ways.

* The Active Employment Strategy announced in the February Economic Statement incorporates a range of specific measures to encourage active job search and participation in the labour force. It seeks to maximise participation and minimise the number of long term unemployed who might otherwise become discouraged job seekers.

* All recipients of the new Job Search Allowance and NEWSTART Allowance, incorporated in the AES, will be required to undertake active job search and/or preparation for employment through training. Under the NEWSTART allowance, which is conditional on such activity, recipients will agree to accept training or other activities assessed by the CES as necessary to improve employment prospects.
* The AES will provide for considerable enhancement of programs and program places to support the increased training activity.
* The changes build on a number of developments that have been introduced by the Government, particularly the successful NEWSTART strategy for the long term unemployed.
* I should mention also the provision made in this year's Budget for assistance to spouses of DSS beneficiaries and pensioners, previously a significant area of hidden unemployment.
- $1.2M has been made available this year, and $2.5 in future years, under the Jobstart and Jobtrain programs which target especially disadvantaged job seekers.

* The Active Employment Strategy includes the most significant changes to assistance to the unemployed, including the hidden unemployed, in almost fifty years. Rather than simply doling out money and consigning people to long term or permanent unemployment, it emphasises training and support in getting people back into the labour market.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great honour to have been elected by the people of Victoria as one of their representatives in this chamber. I believe the Senate performs an indispensable role in our system of government. I am one who strongly supports the role of upper Houses in the Westminster system. Many of the developments in the Senate in the last two decades have enabled this chamber to act as a more effective House of review-a trend the founding fathers of our Constitution would have viewed favourably. The increasing powers of executive government have further emphasised the need for effective upper Houses. This chamber has acted responsibly in carrying out its constitutional duties.

SPEECH.PARA: My introduction to the Senate came when I was senior private secretary to Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. I was fortunate to work with Dame Margaret for five years. As one of the Liberal Party's and this nation's distinguished politicians, Dame Margaret showed that politics could be conducted with dignity and decency. She showed that a successful political career could be built without vicious personal denigration of opponents; that politics in sensitive portfolios could be conducted successfully without sordid deals with vested interests. I also had the great honour to work for a short period of time on the staff of Andrew Peacock, a man whom I regard as a great Liberal and good friend.

I come to this chamber after seven years at the Institute of Public Affairs (IPA), one of a number of private sector think tanks which expanded its activities in the 1980s. It was a valuable experience to work at the IPA with such talented people as Des Moore, Ken Baker, Dame Leonie Kramer, Hugh Morgan, Les McCarrey, Charles Goode and Sir James Balderstone.

The IPA has been active in promoting such public policy issues as smaller government, privatisation and micro reform. From time to time people as eminent as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) used to call such people troglodytes and reactionaries. Other observers, happily, have pointed to the significant role that these think tanks are having in promoting more market-oriented policies. On Wednesday, the Prime Minister said that he had changed his mind about privatisation. We on this side hope that he will change his mind about other policies such as the accord.

We welcome the Government's new approach on privatisation. But its task in selling this new agenda to its own party has undoubtedly been made more difficult by its cynical attempt to whip up anti-privatisation fever in recent Federal and State elections.

I am very conscious of the support that I have received from many people in seeking a political career. I would like to take a few moments to acknowledge some who have been especially important to me. I am delighted that my wife, Daniele, and daughter, Nathalie, are in the gallery today. My son, Alexander, could not join the family because of other commitments. Without Daniele's strong support, it would not have been possible for me to stand for election. I am also pleased that my family are joined by my sister Rosemary and brother David, the honourable member for Goldstein.

One of the great blessings anyone can receive is to have devoted parents. Here I count myself particularly rich. My mother has always had a very active interest in the wider concerns of politics, but I record here today how much I admire her other qualities, her family commitment, strength of character, her erudition and Christian principles.

My father was one of the founders of the Institute of Public Affairs, its Executive Director for more than 30 years, and, I might say, its inspiration. In this role he was very active in promoting the free enterprise philosophy. The importance of his work in this area has been acknowledged by a number of recent studies. He was a leading opponent of the fashionable socialist view which had achieved a degree of dominance in academic and, to a certain degree, in public service circles in the 1940s and 1950s. In that period he was one of what were an endangered species: a free enterprise economist. It has been generally acknowledged that his work made an important contribution towards turning back the onrush of socialism in Australia after the War. He was one of those who helped establish the intellectual climate in this country which contributed towards the final defeat of socialism as a credible philosophy in the 1980s.

I am proud to be part of the Liberal Party. I believe its traditions and principles reflect the values, hopes and aspirations of most Australians. My involvement with Liberal politics started at the University of Melbourne in the mid-1960s. I regularly meet with Liberal students, and it is particularly encouraging to me to witness the strength of the Liberal movement on so many campuses today. The vigour of the Liberal student movement reflects in part the strong reform agenda of liberalism in the 1990s. The Liberal Party of the 1990s has a special appeal to youth. Our platform calls for major economic and social reforms, which have often been vigorously pushed by Liberal students. I commend the Liberal student movement for its initiatives in promoting such important issues as voluntary student unionism.

I am conscious that my election to this chamber reflects the outstanding performance of the Liberal Party in Victoria in the last Federal elections. Anyone who is No. 3 on a Senate ticket-and I guess there are a few here today-benefits greatly from the effectiveness of his fellow State and Federal politicians. The strength of the Liberal Party organisation under Michael Kroger and Petro Georgiou also contributed mightily to the splendid State result we received in the last election. My good friends Julie Reid and Charles Gilles were with me at the beginning.

I believe the philosophy of the Liberal Party, with its emphasis on the individual, free enterprise and liberty, is as relevant to the needs of the Australian people today as it was in the period of Alfred Deakin or Sir Robert Menzies. Indeed, of all the political philosophies that have dominated this century, it is liberalism as we recognise it in this country, and liberalism alone, that has stood the test of time. Who would now stand in this chamber and advocate socialism? Liberalism provides a rational framework for policy. Any philosophy which is not compatible with promoting maximum opportunities for the individual, which does not recognise the vital role of free enterprise and which does not protect the individual from oppressive governments and institutions, is doomed to failure in Australia. Therefore, I view with the deepest concern the development of what has been termed widely the corporate state in Australia, with its attendant powerful lobby groups claiming a key role in government decision making. There have been too many decisions that have not been in the public interest but have been to the advantage of powerful vocal special interests.

The Liberal Party offers a sharp contrast to that corporate state approach. Our guiding philosophy requires the party to pay particular heed not so much to the trade union bosses as to the trade union members; not to the powerful and sometimes politicised environmental groups, but to all Australians who are concerned about the environment; not to the social planners, but to the families struggling to bring up their children in a failing economy; and not to powerful business interests, but to the 700,000 men and women who are running Australia's small business enterprises. I view with a considerable amount of pride that the Liberal Party in so many areas is now regarded as setting the agenda for change.

As I have mentioned, the policies upon which our opponents regularly heaped contempt just a few short years ago, such as privatisation, labour market reform, smaller government and tariff reform are now the lights on the hill illuminating the direction in which the Government must go. Liberalism does not accept the view that politics and political processes provide the main answers to our economic and social problems. The wealth of our society lies in the experience and knowledge of our people. It is for this reason that our Liberal philosophy attempts to limit the political domain and emphasises the need for strong independent institutions to protect the individual and the community from executive power. Who would argue now with the fact that Australia would be a better place today if a number of our vital institutions, such as the Reserve Bank of Australia, had been able and prepared to adopt a role more independent of government?

The alarming decline of an independent Public Service ethic has not, in my view, strengthened our body politic and is one of the factors behind the debacles that we have seen in public administration in the last decade. We are now witnessing a strong move to conscript our universities into the corporate state. Government policies, in recent years, I regret to say, have savagely limited their independence.

I do not believe that the intensely political role that the trade union leadership seeks to play in Australia benefits this nation or, indeed, the trade union movement itself. Like the major business lobby groups, the Australian Council of Trade Unions has no right to claim a special role in government decision making. I believe that this unique period in Australian history, when the trade union leadership has been effectively given a place at the Cabinet table, is now coming to an end. Australia's experiment with corporatism has been a disastrous failure. Despite the huge privileges which have been granted to trade unions, membership continues to decline as workers rebel against a union system which is not responsive to their own needs and has, in recent years, delivered falling living standards. The reform of the trade union movement must be an important element in any program of micro reform.

The Liberal Party supports trade unionism. Our program spells out how we can make trade unions more responsive to their members. A paradox which will not be lost on some observers is that the Liberal Party policy of voluntary enterprise unions which are fully accountable to their members may well be the only way to arrest the decline of unionism in this country. We need more, not fewer, unions; but the focus of this new union movement must be in the factories and business enterprises around Australia, representing directly and intimately the real interests of workers.

I now come to a matter at the forefront of public debate. The Liberal Party philosophy emphasises that competitive markets are better than political processes, which are so often captured by special interests at reflecting individual needs and values. I see the Liberal Party program of privatisation as a means of increasing real public control and influence in many of our enterprises now under government control and ownership. Monopoly power, allied with a ready access to the public purse, often creates government enterprises which are insensitive to community needs, as well as being inefficient in their use of scarce resources.

Australia has barely commenced the historic process of freeing its economy from large intrusive government. Overseas observers would undoubtedly be shocked by the pain in government circles caused by the partial privatisation of a few government enterprises. This is not to deny that government will continue to play an important role in the overall management of the economy-of course it will-but this does not mean that government should be in the business of regulating every nook and cranny of our economy or running business enterprises which would be run much more effectively in the private sector, as Senator Crane outlined this morning in his first speech.

In many ways the decade of the 1980s is one of which Australia cannot be proud. By almost every comparative measure, Australia is in a worse position than at the start of the 1980s. I believe history books will record this period as a wasted decade. It has been a decade marked by economic failure. The scandals we have seen in government administration in Victoria and Western Australia, which have cost the Australian community billions upon billions of dollars, have no parallel in our history. The widespread corporate abuses of the 1980s have brought Australian business reputation to an all-time low. The economic standing of our nation is reflected in the oft-repeated statement that we are heading for Third World status.

The leading British journal the Economist publishes each week a series of comparative tables on the performance of major world economies. In practically every area-inflation, interest rates and balance of payments deficits-Australia has been one of the poorest performing economies. And to top it all off, we are now in the process of entering a serious recession caused essentially by internal economic mismanagement rather than, as in the past, external factors.

The malaise affecting Australia is not only economic. I have already pointed to the decline of some of our public institutions and the trade union movement. I would like to comment on some aspects of the legacy with which we have been left from the last decade. Survey after survey has indicated that politicians and parliament are at present held in low esteem by the public.

I welcome the lead that John Hewson has given in the short time he has headed the Opposition in highlighting the need to improve the operations of parliament and the behaviour of parliamentarians. The scandals which have plagued government administration and the business community have undermined public confidence in some of our central institutions. Perhaps the most serious has been the alarming decline in community standards. The increase in crime and mindless vandalism is well-known and well-documented. Deregulation in the business area gives greater freedom to individuals and managers. It has not always been accompanied by a necessary and corresponding increase in business and community responsibility. Freedom unaccompanied by responsibility leads to anarchy and the law of the jungle. Responsibility, we should always bear in mind, is the other side of the coin of freedom. The two are indivisible.

I want to speak a little on living standards. Australia's economic failure in the 1980s is reflected in the stagnation of family living standards. Real wages, for the first time since the war, have declined for most of the decade. This is a direct result of the accord, a savage tax regime which discriminates against families with children. The economic crisis in which we find ourselves will almost certainly ensure that family living standards will continue to decline.

A recent report showed that in no other period since 1945 has there been such a dramatic decline in living standards for the person on average weekly earnings. It is worth recalling that, in the period just after World War II, the individual on average earnings with a dependent spouse and two children effectively paid no taxes. I believe it is a central priority that not only do we carry out the economic reforms which will ensure Australian living standards can commence to rise again, but also we must look closely at the tax-government spending regime which imposes such heavy burdens on families.

I now want to highlight an extraordinary feature of economic management over the last 20 years; that is, the acceptance of high unemployment as part of our economic arrangements. I agree with Mr Keating that unemployment is the major cause of poverty in this country. It is worth recalling that in the postwar period there was a consensus between the major political parties that high levels of unemployment could no longer be tolerated and for almost a quarter of a century unemployment figures were at levels which, by the standards of the 1970s and 1980s, could be considered unattainable.

The lack of interest in the issue of unemployment reflects, I believe, an unwillingness to and, indeed, a fear of tackling labour market rigidities and the disincentives in our social welfare system. The latest figures show that, among young people in the 15 to 19 years age group looking for work, unemployment is now over 20 per cent and rising. In earlier periods, in the time of Chifley and Menzies, this would have been regarded as a national scandal. I believe that the Senate can help put a full employment policy back on the public agenda. We should conduct an inquiry into examining the methods by which we can return to a full employment economy. Do we believe what our predecessors could achieve in the 1950s and 1960s is beyond us in the 1980s and 1990s?

I have a particular interest in the development of small business in Australia. Small business, as Peter Boyle, the National Director of the Australian Small Business Association, points out, does not seem to rank in any importance in Australia's corporate state. Small business is one of the great outsiders. I agree with Peter Boyle when he argues that the single most important assistance for small business would be the deregulation of the labour market.

I refer to the high interest rate policies pursued by government and its effect on small business. Comparative interest rates for business borrowings in Australia have been 5 to 8 per cent higher than those of our major competitors. This differential has been largely constant for the last eight years. It has come about as a deliberate policy and has had savage effects on business competitiveness and family living standards. How we can expect a major export industry to develop in this high interest rate environment is beyond comprehension.

In the 1980s Australia failed to address the major economic problems facing the nation. The lack of will in the economic arena can perhaps in part be traced to the negativism and lack of confidence that too many of our opinion leaders have in our nation. I say this because another feature of the last decade has been the growing tendency to denigrate our past without any sense of our nation's great achievements. This is clearly demonstrated by the debate surrounding the bicentennial program in which Senator Shirley Walters played quite a prominent role.

I have long been of the opinion that there is an astonishing gulf between the guilt-ridden view that many of our so-called elites have of Australia and the patriotism of our people. For those who may doubt this statement, I invite them to read the number of denigrating and uninspired histories of Australia which were released during the year. My good friend Ken Baker at the Institute of Public Affairs has been very effective at bringing this issue to public attention.
In 1988 Time Australia published a feature essay by a man often acclaimed as Australia's leading historian, Professor Manning Clark. It read, in part:

. . . the coming of the British was the occasion of three great evils: the violence against the original inhabitants of the country . . . the violence against the first European labour force in Australia, the convicts; and the violence done to the land itself.

The same year saw the publication of the four volume A People's History of Australia Since 1788. This has been listed as a general resource in the course development and support material for the new Victorian Certificate of Education in Australian Studies in Victoria. It frankly admits in its editors' comments:
This history is critical-
It continues as follows:
Held up against the millennia of Aboriginal experience, the last 200 years seem but a brief, nasty interlude.

This history, the editors claim, rejects myths of national progress and unity. Will this encourage schoolchildren to view their forebears with pride or with shame? Will it encourage them to work for a better Australia? The answer, I believe, is no.
Of course, Australian history has not been without its injustices and cruelties. Geoffrey Blainey, who is a notable exception to the tendency to look with rancour on the past, has written:
In the past 200 years Australia has had powerful achievements and every part of the nation has contributed to them.
Professor Blainey writes:
A people's sense of history can unite or it can divide them. It is hard to instil a sense of purpose in a people who believe that history which formed them is worthless.

It is of great importance, Mr Deputy President, that the students of today have a proper appreciation of the achievements of our nation, of the struggles of our pioneer men and women, and of their fortitude and their courage.

The failure of the 1980s is in many ways a failure of leadership. It is not that we lack resources. Indeed, Australia is immensely wealthy in terms of its mineral and land resources. It is not that our people are not enterprising. Indeed, as a nation we can draw on the enormous vigour and determination of a migrant heritage. It is not that our people lack a strong commitment to our nation. There is every evidence that the Australian public has an uncommonly high degree of patriotic feeling compared with other nations, as I have mentioned.

The problem is this: our leaders have constantly told us that their policies are working. How can we hope to address our economic problems when our political leadership will not take people into its confidence? The Australian people are waiting for leadership. The Liberal Party has a detailed program of reform, a philosophy reflecting basic Australian values, and a leadership determined to take the Australian people into its confidence and to honestly inform them of the steps which must be taken to put Australia back on the road to prosperity. It has a clear vision for Australia. I will be working to implement that vision.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I add my congratulations to Senator Kemp on his maiden speech. He gave a lucid exposition of the philosophy he espouses. I also join with Senator Evans in praising Senator Kemp for his connections with Dame Margaret Guilfoyle.
—Not too much.

—I think we can give high praise to Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, no matter when, Senator McKiernan. Before lunch I was talking about amalgamations and the fact that unions have a history of amalgamations. Indeed, so do employer organisations. Perhaps the classic example of amalgamations is those unions which have gone into making the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union. I have been speaking of the amalgamations which have taken place since 1972. In 1976 the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union amalgamated with the Federated Shipwrights and Ship Constructors Association to become the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union-the name was not changed.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1982 the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union and the Federated Moulders Metal Union of Australia combined to become, again, the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union. I think it is presently in the process of amalgamating with ADSTE, the Association of Drafting, Supervisory and Technical Employees.

The Metal Workers Union is a classic example of the benefits to be obtained from amalgamation. That union has done mighty work for its members and for the nation as a whole. One illustration, of course, is the way the Victorian branch of that union saved the shipbuilding yards at Williamstown and has helped to make them a viable and major economic unit in the economy of not only Victoria but also Australia as a whole.

So amalgamation is a process which is needed and which should be facilitated, and that is what this Bill does. It does it in the grand traditions of democracy. The amalgamations that will take place as a result of the Bill will take place pursuant to ballots by members of the unions which are to amalgamate. Senator McLean has referred to an exception to that and has quite accurately said that it is a proper exemption in the circumstances. He looked at that first. He had some reservations about it, but he is now assured that that exemption from the ballot is a proper procedure.
The Bill starts off by adding objectives to the Industrial Relations Act 1988, which I have already discussed. It then goes on to talk about demarcation disputes in this context:
In exercising its power in relation to a demarcation dispute, the Commission:
(a) must consider whether it should consult with appropriate peak councils that are representatives of organisations representing employees or organisations representing employers; and
(b) may consult with appropriate peak councils.

The Commission already has power to settle demarcation disputes by awarding work to a particular union. This enables it to make reference to peak organisations in reaching its decision, and that is a sensible reform.

The next clause I ought to refer to is clause 12, which sets 20,000 as the minimum number for a union. Again, this has been taken up by Senator Durack and Senator McLean. That figure is subject to an order by the designated presidential member that a small organisation may continue to exist if it is in the public interest for it to do so. Even though the standard is to be 20,000, the new legislation contains a provision to enable a much smaller union to exist if it is in the public interest to do so. It is not an overriding provision for a minimum number, but it is the standard which must be met unless it can be shown that a smaller number is appropriate.

As I have been going through these matters I have noticed the entrance of Senator Burns into the chamber. In speaking of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union earlier, I should have paid tribute to him. He was the president of that union in Queensland, served it with great distinction and has brought into this chamber the experience he gained over the years. He has served this chamber with a great deal of merit and his presence has been of great benefit to the Senate, to the Government and the nation generally. I think that he is in agreement with the provisions of this legislation.
I turn to the question of federations. This is a new concept that has been brought into the Act in the following way. Proposed section 236 reads:
The existing organisations concerned in a proposed amalgamation may jointly lodge in the Industrial Registry an application for recognition as a federation.

It goes on to talk about that provision. It is envisaged that where organisations which propose to enter an amalgamation want to join a closer relationship in the meantime they can do so under the provisions of proposed section 236. Before the ballot is taken they are able to come to some sort of relationship that is preparatory to a full amalgamation at a later date. That eases the way to amalgamation in a way that is not presently available and ultimately lends itself to a better organisation.

Proposed section 240 talks about approval by the committee of management. Before an amalgamation takes place the committee of management of the unions proposing to amalgamate must agree to a scheme by which the amalgamation will be forwarded.

Proposed section 241 talks about the community of interest declaration that the organisations that are to amalgamate must exhibit before the presidential member gives the go ahead for the amalgamation.

The provisions of the Act set out how the Industrial Relations Commission is to supervise the process of amalgamation. Proposed section 248 talks about how the Australian Electoral Commission is to be notified. It should be pointed out to those listening that the ballot for amalgamation is to be conducted by the Australian Electoral Commission, except in certain circumstances. The general rule will be that the Australian Electoral Commission will conduct a ballot by which the amalgamations are to take place.

There is provision within the new legislation for Yes and No cases for amalgamation to be put to the members. There is provision under proposed section 253J for a secret ballot of the members. There is provision under proposed section 253N for the way in which the approval of the amalgamation is to be forwarded after the ballot is conducted.

Proposed section 253ZD talks about validation of certain acts done in good faith. This is to cover a situation where there may be faults in the process under which the amalgamation takes place but which have been done in good faith. This gives power to the court to validate steps.

That is a very quick run through of the provisions of the legislation, but it is enough to illustrate that the whole process of amalgamation is to be done in the context of a democratic process. The Industrial Relations Act 1988 ensures that democratic processes will be followed and ensures the ability of members of unions and of organisations registered under the Act to take a full part in the running of the organisations. It is therefore in keeping with the general thrust of the legislation brought down by this Government and it deserves to be supported.

The tabling of these Finance minutes today reflects the ongoing concern of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in the accountability of the Executive to the Parliament. Arrangements to ensure that appropriate action is taken in response to comments contained in the Committee's reports have been in operation since 1952. The arrangements have been that after a report by the Committee is tabled in the Senate and the House of Representatives, the Chairman of the Committee forwards a copy of the report to the responsible Minister. A copy is also forwarded to the Minister for Finance together with a request that the report be considered, and the Chairman subsequently be informed of actions to address the Committee's recommendations. The reply, in the form of a Department of Finance Minute, is then examined by the Committee and submitted, with comment if necessary, as a report to the Parliament.

In its Report No. 291, Revised Procedures for Reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which was tabled in June 1988, the Committee advised that it would consolidate the tabling of all Finance Minutes into one annual report; the only exceptions being Finance Minutes that were urgent, lengthy or for some other reason required immediate reporting to the Parliament. The Committee tabled a consolidated volume of Finance Minutes for the first time in November last year. This consolidated volume of Finance Minutes was the Committee's 301st Report, appropriately entitled Finance Minutes! In this report the Committee noted that it intended to continue the practice of tabling all Finance Minutes received in a particular year within one volume, but that it also intended to make each Finance Minute available to Parliament as soon as practicable after it is received by the Committee. The reason for this action is to facilitate the progress of accountability. This action involves a slight revision of the procedures for handling Finance Minutes which were outlined in Report 291, which referred to only an annual tabling of Finance Minutes.

The Committee believes that the overall process of accountability is aided by the prompt tabling of Finance Minutes. This gives parliamentarians and the public an opportunity to comment on the adequacy or otherwise of the responses by the departments to particular concerns and recommendations of the Committee. In turn, the Committee can only benefit from taking account of such comment when it considers the Finance Minute in detail at a later stage.

The tabling of these Finance Minutes should not be taken to mean that the Committee is satisfied with the contents of the Minutes as the Committee reserves the prerogative of conducting detailed analysis of a particular Finance Minute at a later date. There have been instances where such analysis has led the Committee to a further formal inquiry. I would stress that while detailed analysis of a Finance Minute may follow-rather than precede-its tabling, this does not indicate the Committee has reduced in any way its oversight of the responses to the reports. Nor does it indicate any reduction in the importance with which the Committee views the Finance Minute process.

The Finance Minutes that I have tabled today deal with three recent reports of the Public Accounts Committee-on engagement of external consultants by commonwealth departments; on efficiency audits on safety principles for explosives in the Department of Defence; and on the Commonwealth's offsets program. I commend them all to honourable senators.
