DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON THE ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION AND THE ARTS-REPORT ON THE POTENTIAL OF KAKADU NATIONAL PARK REGION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts on the potential of Kakadu National Park region and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I protest at the lateness of this response. I make the point that the presentation of this response has been rescheduled at least three times this afternoon.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate has been waiting for this report since November 1988. I believe that the only reason it has been made available at this time is as a result of the change of chairmanship of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts. Recently Senator Rosemary Crowley succeeded Senator Black as Chairman of the Committee. Obviously, Senator Crowley demanded that some action be taken. The previous Chairman, Senator Black, was also engaged in the preparation of the report dealing with drugs in sport. I believe that that was a worthwhile inquiry. Unfortunately, it tended to put this report to one side.

The response praises the beauty of Kakadu National Park. I totally agree with that comment. I spent quite a bit of time in the park when the Committee conducted inspections. We visited the better places, the drier places, the places where the buffalo herd used to run, Mudginberri station and other places. I certainly agree that it is a beautiful place and should be preserved.

That does not mean that we should not be looking at other uses for Kakadu. As I said, I have no argument with what has already been done, that is, the extension of the third phase of the Kakadu National Park by some 2,000 square kilometres. However, one must also look at other uses for the park.

The company that obtained leases at Coronation Hill many years ago was given every indication that if suitable ore was found there would be a fair possibility that mining would be permitted. This Government has done nothing but delay. Two inquiries are under way at the moment. One is considering the situation in sleeping sickness country and the other is centred on the South Alligator River. These inquiries have been going for a long time.

I remember the Government saying just before the election, when it was supposed to make a decision as to whether mining was going ahead or not, that that decision would be made after the election. That was a good six months ago now. Unfortunately, the Government has found another excuse for not making a decision. Page 1 of the report states:

Kakadu conservation has been almost entirely incorporated in stage 3 of the park. A new 48 square kilometre conservation zone is the subject of comprehensive and concurrent inquiry processes relating to land use options for the entire zone. A resource assessment commission (RAC) inquiry is covering environmental and economic considerations. A second inquiry is being conducted by the chairman of the RAC and using common resources examining Aboriginal heritage.
That second inquiry, as I mentioned previously, is centred on the sleeping sickness country. Then follows, as far as I am concerned, the most relevant two lines in the report:
A decision on the Coronation Hill project will be made following the Government's consideration of reports from these two inquiries.

How long do the people of Australia have to wait to make use of sustainable resources in Australia before the Government finally comes to a decision? I believe that if there is something to be done, we should look for an excuse to do it, not an excuse not to do it. That is the case here. There have been several inquiries. How many more inquiries are around the corner before the Government finally makes a decision?

How many more inquiries are there around the corner which will delay making a final decision? I believe that we will not get a decision during the term of this Government. If the Government makes a decision against mining, so be it, but this matter has been dragging on and on without a decision being made one way or the other.

The exploration work on Coronation Hill, as I said before, has been going on for a long time. When the Committee was looking at the park and the proposed mining venture, the company produced a table showing some of the drilling results. I read the results as fast as I could, and some of them were quite fantastic. Up to 400 ounces a tonne were found in some drill holes. Australia could do with projects such as that but, unfortunately, a decision is not being made one way or the other.

Putting Coronation Hill into perspective in relation to Kakadu National Park, the area is minute. Anyone who listens to the noises made by the radicals and those who want all resources closed up around Australia would think that Coronation Hill covered a large area in the better part of Kakadu. However, my view is that it is in the less pristine area of Kakadu National Park and certainly does not cover a great area. It is in stage 3, as I have said, and is minute in area when compared with the rest of the park.

In addition to the tables, the company constructed a contour model of the whole park. It was roughly one metre by two metres in size. One fellow said, BHP's proposed mine at Coronation Hill is in the model. Can you find it?'. Everybody looked, and then the man reached over into the middle of this contour map of Kakadu National Park and indicated a little area that was no more than half a centimetre square on the side of the hill; it was minimal. I was hoping to do a comparison of the size of that area with Kakadu National Park, but I have not been able to due to the report having been called on at short notice. However, it was very minute and was in a not very pristine area of the park. So when these radical groups-and I believe the Government is playing along with them to a certain extent-put out this sort of propaganda on size and the damage mining will do, I wish they would give us the proper perspective, because the area is minimal.

Millions of dollars have been expended by the company in its search for gold. It has not been able to get any result because of this Government's delay in coming to a decision. As I said before, if the Government made a decision that was against mining in Kakadu National Park, so be it. The company could then make a decision on whether it moved off or waited for appeals in the hope that the decision would be overturned. But no, this Government is just delaying and doing nothing about it.
We have been waiting for this response since November 1988. Part of the reason for that delay was to get the last elections out of the way. That having been done, we still wait for the decision.

I will now detail some aspects unrelated to the Coronation Hill matter. I was associated with the minority report of the Committee, which looked at other aspects of the inquiry, such as commercial fishing. That report recommended that the commercial fishing organisations that would be affected by the recommendations should be given some sort of compensation. That would not set such a great precedent because these things have been done before. A certain amount of compensation has been paid already, but obviously not enough, regarding the logging of certain forests in Australia.

Shark Bay has been included in the Government's hit list, although the Government denied about two years ago that it had ever heard of Shark Bay. The then Minister, Senator Richardson, denied that the Government had any proposals involving Shark Bay, but it now seems that the area will be closed off. I believe that compensation should be given to pastoralists and tourist operators who may be driven from the region. The Government has decided that no compensation will be paid to those in the fishing industry who will be affected by its decisions.

At the time of the inquiry into Kakadu National Park, much was made about the buffalo herd. Honourable senators will remember the famous remark by Senator Evans, probably while flying over the area, that it was only clapped-out buffalo country.

I know that there were problems with brucellosis in the buffalo herd there, but there was a big drive to shoot the animals, to get rid of them, and ultimately most of them were destroyed. That activity was related to the Mudginberri station and the famous Mudginberri meatworks, which a lot of those on the other side of this chamber would like to forget. The National Farmers Federation and my colleague-I am proud to say-Senator Winston Crane, who made an excellent maiden speech today, along with Senator Kemp, took on the unions at Mudginberri.

With the elimination of most of the buffalo herd, the meatworks closed down. I am aware now, though it was not known to me at the time, that a buffalo herd, one hopes free from brucellosis, has been reintroduced to the region, for the purpose of providing rations for the Aborigines. That is good thinking. Many fears were expressed at the time the buffaloes were shot. The mentality of some of the radical groups who wanted to get rid of the buffaloes went beyond logic. Though there were campaigns to save the whales, to save the ducks in Western Australia, to save this and that, when it came to the buffaloes, which are beautiful looking animals I believe and part of the staple diet of the Indians in the mid-west of the United States of America years ago, I was surprised at their attitude. Only eight or nine years down the track that attitude has been reversed and a new buffalo herd has been introduced to provide food for the Aborigines.

Returning to what I said before, some fears have been expressed that certain weeds that only the buffaloes ate-from my experience in the grain area, I would describe them as tumbleweeds-have gone wild. Certain moves have been made to start aerial spraying in order to control the weeds that have taken over. It is two or three years since I have been to Kakadu National Park but, hopefully, due to the controlled introduction of brucellosis-free buffalo, some of the problems with the weeds might be eliminated. I look forward to the day when a reasonable number of buffalo herds return to the area, because natural control of those weeds is far better than aerial spraying, with all of its attendant problems. Furthermore, when there is a build-up of these weeds, other natural vegetation in the park is stifled off. So one can see that eliminating even an introduced species such as the buffalo has its side effects.

The Government spokesman mentioned taking up the recommendations concerning the Office of the Supervising Scientist. I have not had time to go into those recommendations in detail because it has been two years since I have seen the report and I was unsure as to whether the subject would be discussed this afternoon, so I am uncertain which recommendations were accepted. The Office of the Supervising Scientist has a very important position in the park. It is funded through Ranger Uranium Mines Pty Ltd and other mines that have operated in the area. Unfortunately, I believe that it has rather run away with itself in terms of its jurisdiction. In our minority report we have recommended that that Office should be moved to Darwin so that it is located in a living city rather than being holed up in the national park all the time. It could then see what it is like to be in the real world.

I certainly believe that the Office did its job on the experimental side in the dissipation of water from the mining sites to natural vegetation. However, I believe that the anti-mining attitude of the Office is rather overzealous. I believe that in Australia today we need mining as much as we need conservation. In other words, we need a balanced situation. However, I will return to the recommendations concerning the Office of the Supervising Scientist at a later time.

The Government in its response has examined the option of putting a levy on mining exploration, if it does get going in Kakadu National Park, to put the proceeds back into the park and into the native communities that operate the park. I believe that that is the right way to go. It will certainly not be the first place in the world where such a measure has been taken up, and hopefully the same situation will apply at Coronation Hill when mining occurs there.

The Committee recommended that a full and detailed plan for rehabilitation should be required before any mining operations are allowed at Coronation Hill. I do not think that companies such as Pancontinental Mining Ltd, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and Gold Mines of Kalgoorlie would even think of starting mining ventures or projects today or putting such a proposition up to the environmental authorities if a detailed report was not in place.

The Government has accepted this recommendation, subject to its getting things moving. The Government recognises that Kakadu is an outstanding example of the original Australia. I agree with that. Much of the value of the area stems from the fact that there has been relatively little human disturbance. Even in the time that we were there, I believe that we probably walked over ground that had hardly ever been walked over by a white man before. Other areas of our continent have been overrun by goats, donkeys, rabbits or weeds. I realise that that has happened, especially in the eastern part of Australia where European colonisation took place. The settlers had no other option but to make a living from what was there, without destroying what was around.

I believe that we have learned many lessons in 200 years. If mining is permitted at Coronation Hill, I am sure that these mistakes would not be repeated. There are measures to make sure that they are not repeated. Many mistakes have been made in the past, and many lessons have been learned; but that does not mean that we have to lock up our resources forever. This is a good time to talk about locking up resources because of the truck blockade around Parliament House in relation to the logging of our forests. I think the trucks are still there after we come in in the morning; we do not get another opportunity to go outside until very late at night. We have got to the stage where we should be looking at what we are doing in locking up our resources because Australia needs to be competitive with the rest of the world. In the two maiden speeches that were delivered today, it was pointed out that we are fast going down the gurgler. Therefore, we have to look at sustainable development. I am certain there is enough good thinking in Australia to ensure that we go down that path.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really appreciate the general tone of this response to the report entitled The Potential of the Kakadu National Park Region by the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts regarding Kakadu National Park, particularly the opening gamut that Kakadu National Park is a very special place. I think anybody who has visited it would agree with that. I draw attention to the final statement in the response, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will continue to give the protection of this globally significant area a very high priority and will not allow any activity that poses the risk of unacceptable damage to the environment.

That is the line that I think is very important to understand. I hope that the Government can follow through with that promise not to allow any risk of unacceptable damage to the environment of Kakadu. Having said that it is a very special place, I think it is important that the Government takes into very careful consideration not only the environmental aspect of life in Kakadu, but also the Aboriginal people's views about what should and should not happen there.

Recently I was very privileged to be able to visit Kakadu National Park. Through the help of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS), I had a very good overview over several days of what is actually happening at the moment in Kakadu in terms of the management of tourism, the management of the fragile ecology and also the inclusion of Aboriginal people in the board of management.

They have had a considerable amount of help in terms of a linguist interpreter but they need financial support-as other groups around the country have had financial support-to make well-considered submissions to the RAC. I was privileged to meet some of the traditional owners among the Jawoyn people. It is very important to put on record that only in a situation where they were under extreme pressure-and I noted that Senator Panizza wanted Senator Crichton-Browne to have a go on this issue later on in the debate-may it be said that certain words were got out of some of the Jawoyn people at a meeting at which Senator Crichton-Browne was present.

I spoke to the traditional owners, and they have been canvassed by so many people. In fact, there is a great deal of exhaustion among the Jawoyn people because they have been asked over and over about this. They say, `Well, how many times do we have to tell you people? We don't want mining to go ahead at Coronation Hill'. It is very significant country to them. It is Sickness Country-Bula country to the Jawoyn people. They believe there will be very adverse reactions if further disturbance of the Bula country is allowed.

Of course, there have been mines in the region before. There are six or seven leftover mines in the so-called conservation zone-very badly named, I might add, because conservation for mining is about what it has been-and there have been, over the period of those mines from the late 1940s, 1950s and 1960s, severe negative consequences for the Jawoyn people in terms of diseases which have gone right through the community. They do attribute this to the disturbance of the Bula country. They believe that if the Coronation Hill mine is allowed to go ahead there will be such severe disturbance of that spirit area in the Sickness Country that it could mean the end of the Jawoyn people.

We really need to take this very seriously on Aboriginal grounds alone. We need to listen to the age old wisdom of the people who have maintained this area, looked after this area, for thousands and thousands of years. Their word ought to be good enough. We should not allow the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) or any other company to mine in the Coronation Hill region or, indeed, in any other part of Kakadu National Park.

SPEECH.PARA: I was describing to the Senate a very complex case of Mr and Mrs Rigg of Nowra who were encouraged by the Commonwealth Bank of Australia to enter into what was known as an offshore borrowing option. Offshore borrowing options became quite common between 1984 and 1986. It is estimated that approximately 1400 Australians were enticed into this attractive bank product and, as a result, went bankrupt and lost their businesses and their farms. I contend that it was a deliberately contrived banking practice that contravened the fiduciary relationship, which is the fundamental obligation on the bank to consider the interests of clients and the interests of the bank equally. It was driven by the new modus operandi under deregulated banking of maximising profit at virtually all cost.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have not people sued banks?

—They have and they have sued successfully. I am being asked whether it is possible to pursue this in a court of law. Of course it is, but it is a question of whether a person has any money left to do that. The very nature of the problem of many people on whose behalf I am speaking today is bankruptcy or a lack of funds. That is their problem. They are often broken not only financially but also emotionally, psychologically and maritally, and most of them are not in a position to proceed. The Riggs are not in a position to proceed. They have been to a court. They are not in a position to proceed to appeal because they are totally without money.
—Are they not entitled to legal aid?

—They are not entitled to legal aid. I was in the process of elaborating on the mechanism of this procedure of offshore borrowing options. I had been citing a number of documents, and I was elaborating on why the bank would insist upon customers accepting an exchange risk, which is an inherent risk in this procedure, as opposed to accepting it itself. I was citing a bank memorandum from the Corporate Banking Division of the Commonwealth Bank, dated July 1984 and entitled, 'Simulated Currency Loans'. It gives an example of simulated currency borrowings that the customer wishes to simulate. 'Simulate' is a key word. We are talking about pretend, unreal loans that never actually become a reality. The memorandum gives an example of a simulated currency borrowing where a customer wishes to borrow a simulated, say, Swiss franc borrowing for the equivalent of, say, $1m for six months. In this example we assume from the starting date of the transaction that the Commonwealth Trading Bank Swiss franc selling rate, the spot rate, is 1.9985, while the six months forward rate is 1.9311. The customer sells forward in Swiss francs for six months to the equivalent of his Australian dollar commitment including interest-that is, $1,064,603 at 1.19311, which equals 2,055,855 Swiss francs. We presume that the spot exchange rate for Australian dollars and Swiss francs does not change between the start date and the maturity date of the transaction. At the maturity date, the customer would receive a compensation payment for the close out of the forward contract.

The sale price of the original contract would be $1,064,603, and the purchase price in Swiss francs, as I said, was 2,055,855. A table shows the consequences of that transaction, and I seek leave to incorporate that brief four-line table, rather than attempt to verbalise it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I haven't seen it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The outstanding feature that emerges from this example is that the customer has already been locked into an expensive bill facility. Upon the drawing down of the bill, the net finance of $1m is credited to his account. Upon the maturity of the bill, the gross amount of $1,064,603 would in the normal course be debited to the account and the customer would be liable for the bill drawing down cost of $64,603. What the bank is saying is that if the customer enters into a simulated foreign currency loan and makes a profit on the exchange risk that profit will soften the bill draw-down costs-in this example by $35,904. It is quite evident that the bank used the exposure to the exchange risk as a marketing ploy to induce customers to accept the expensive bill facility. What is happening therefore is that this softening of the risk is being used to induce people into transactions. The other reason for the bank insisting upon its customers accepting an exchange risk is self-evident. In the example given above, there is a qualification:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the final result of a simulated borrowing, as with an actual foreign currency borrowing, will depend upon the movement in the spot rate of exchange for the currency(ies) involved.

What this means, in effect, is that if there was a downward movement in the Australian dollar against the Swiss franc, the customer would suffer a loss and that loss would be added to the bill's draw-down costs. If the bank had been honest it would also have given an example showing how the exchange loss would increase the bill's draw-down costs, but of course the bank was not motivated by honesty; the bank was motivated by greed, as I outlined yesterday.

On 9 October 1984, the bank held a seminar at Wollongong. Mr Rigg's financial adviser attended the seminar. Mr Rigg later attended a similar seminar at Nowra. SPEECH.PARA: The bank even congratulated itself on the representations made to Mr Rigg and his financial adviser. A bank memorandum of Mr W. J. O'Reilly, Acting Senior Manager, Nowra Branch, dated 6 May 1985 states:

. . . an invitation was extended to Mr Rigg to attend a seminar conducted by this office by Group Treasury staff on foreign currency lending. Mr Rigg was impressed with the obvious expertise the bank has in that area.

The memorandum, which was addressed to the Regional Manager, also stated:

Your office is well aware of our recent marketing efforts in this area and the substantial gains made from other banks. Approval of this application will further our sound reputation in the local business community.

When Mr O'Reilly wrote those words he was not to know that the approval of that application would lead to the bank being regarded with hatred, ridicule and contempt by the local business community for the manner in which it breached its fiduciary responsibility and pursued a practice which subsequently sent approximately 1,400 small businesses to the wall.

The bank did not provide to Mr and Mrs Rigg the bills discount facility in accordance with the market practice. The bank did not provide to Mr and Mrs Rigg the simulated foreign currency loan. On 7 April 1986 the bank offered Mr and Mrs Rigg, and Mr and Mrs Rigg accepted, a fixed rate bills discount facility. The bank did not provide that facility either. What the bank did was to provide a series of sham bill transactions, whereby the bank pocketed not only the usual fees and margins, but the interest as well. Moreover, the bank, by fraud, debited the bills roll-over costs to an overdraft account of the company, thereby earning additional compounded overdraft interest on these debits.

The consequence of that fraudulent conduct was that the bank absorbed the company's working capital and crippled the business, thereby destroying valuable export earnings for Australia. The Senate will recall that I cited an example in which I made similar observations about the Huon Valley Springs saga.

The bank well knew the standing and potential of Mr Rigg's business. The bank well knew the consequences to Mr Rigg and his family that would flow from any fraudulent misconduct. I refer again to the memorandum dated 6 May 1985:

Mr Rigg has proven management ability and the Company has shown it can operate profitably . . . The arrangement with Lysaght Brownbuilt Industries and the assistance of the Department of Trade should ensure that lucrative overseas markets will open up . . . This will be the first simulated borrowing at this office where an exporter has been involved.

Earlier I suggested that if the bank wanted to go behind market practice with a sham transaction, it would discount the bill to itself and insert its own name as an acceptor of the bill-a procedure which I outlined yesterday. The bill would be kept at the customer's branch of the bank and would not be negotiated on the open money market. That is what happened in the Rigg incident.
The seeds for the fraud were sown in the memorandum dated 6 May 1985, where the Riggs' repayment capacity was demonstrated, in summary, as follows:
A T &D A Rigg:...86,000
Tony Rigg Welding and Manufac-
turing P/L:...56,470
Their total capacity to pay was $142,470, less various items amounting to $24,800; the net amount was $117,670. The memorandum concluded:
$117,670 will be available to meet an estimated interest expense per annum of $75,175 on the bills discount/endorsement facility of $485,000 . . .

What the bank was saying was that the capacity of Mr and Mrs Rigg to service the bill facility would be dependent upon utilisation of the income of the company to supplement income derived from Mr and Mrs Rigg. This was taken further in a letter from the bank to Mr and Mrs Rigg dated 26 February 1986. I quote:

. . . we have reservations as to your ability to meet interest costs on your indebtedness once the development is fully completed and tenanted. The following table is an assessment of estimated net income and interest costs . . .
There is a table of about eight lines which is in fact contained within the letter. I seek leave to incorporate that table in Hansard.

Net rental income
Less rental payable by Tony Rigg Welding &Manufacturing Pty Limited:...

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The bank is now saying that the whole of the net income of the company will be required to service the loan-a different requirement from that which it had outlined in a previous memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: The bank is now foreshadowing an interest rate of 20 per cent per annum on the bill facility. The bank is now foreshadowing that the servicing of that exorbitant interest rate will absorb all the income of Mr and Mrs Rigg in the company. What happened to the simulated foreign currency loan? What happened to the overall interest factor of 5.66 per cent, shown in the earlier table in the bank memorandum dated July 1984? What happened to Mr Henshaw's estimated 8 per cent per annum in the light of this now incurred 20 per cent per annum?

How could the bank take the benefit of the 20 per cent interest for itself? The answer is simple: discount the bill to itself. That is what happened-because it had left this option open to itself. How could the bank ensure that the net income of the company serviced the interest? The answer is simple: debit the interest to the overdraft account of the company. That is what happened.

However, there was a problem. If the net income of the company was to service the interest, the only working capital available to the company was the overdraft facility. If the interest payments were debited to the overdraft account, those debits could take the overdraft over the approved limit, causing the bank to bounce cheques and effectively cripple the business-and that is what happened.
Indeed, the bank well knew the consequences of its fraudulent conduct. In a diary note by Mr G. S. Judge, Senior Manager of the Nowra branch, it is stated:
Mr Rigg telephoned to complain about the dishonour of the company cheque for $4,310. Interest of $6,860.80 was charged on 23 December 1986 which took the balance over the temporary limit of $138,000.

Mr Judge knew the bank was crippling the Riggs' business. Why did he do nothing about it? Why did he not reverse the fraudulent debits out of the overdraft account? Why did he not implement a simulated loan without exchange risk?
In a letter from Mr G. R. S. Kyngdon to Rigg, dated 19 February 1987, it was stated:

We understand your concern that the interest charges on the bills are placing heavy pressure on the company's overdraft account and restricting your ability to continue to trade. To alleviate this problem we are prepared to allow temporary excesses on the overdraft account of 150,000 . . .

I would normally have sought leave to table that letter, but a copy is available. That was a stupid and meaningless gesture. The next interest debit took the overdraft over the new limit. Kyngdon knew the bank was crippling Rigg's business. Why did he do nothing effective about it? Why did he not reverse the fraudulent debits out of the overdraft account? Why did he not implement a simulated loan without exchange risk?

I suggest that the reason Judge and Kyngdon did nothing effective was that they did not want to. I suggest that the bank had embarked upon a deliberate strategy calculated to extract every last drop out of the Riggs. I suggest that the bank did not care if the Rigg business was crippled. I suggest further that the bank wanted Rigg to go under, so that the bank could realise on its first mortgage security. In June 1987 the bank's fraudulent conduct finally crippled Rigg's business. A letter from Mr G. S. Judge to the company dated 19 June 1987 stated:
We regret that we are not in a position to honour further drawings including your weekly wage cheque unless covering funds are provided.
I would normally have sought leave to table that letter.

I turn now to the documentary evidence of the fraud. Bills were drawn down or rolled over on 34 separate occasions. Upon each occasion the transaction was evidenced by various documents prepared and issued by the bank. The first bill was discounted on 14 August 1985. The action sheet prepared at the bank's Nowra branch shows the following: first, the names of the customers were A. T. and D. A. Rigg. All subsequent actions named the customers as A. T. and D. A. Rigg. Second, the account number of the customers was 181.407. That number was crossed out and the number 181.415 inserted, that is, the current number of the overdraft account of the company. That is significant. That action enabled the fraud whereby the bill draw-down, or roll-over costs, representing interest on the transaction, together with the bank's usual fees and margins, were debited to the overdraft account of the company. All subsequent action sheets nominated the account number of 181.415. The third matter appearing on the action sheet was that upon the draw-down of the bill the net proceeds of the transaction, that is, the face value of the bill less the interest, fees and margins, were credited to account No. 181.829. All subsequent action sheets showed the net proceeds as crediting account No. 181.415 or, when the bank's accounting procedures were changed, showing the interest and margins as fees debited to the account, which had the same result for the customer.

I have only a little more to present and I shall have to return to this on a future occasion. What I am doing, quite deliberately, is putting into the Hansard a classic case of the exercise of the overseas currency option debacle. The Rigg case is an outstanding one, and I am putting it in detail so that it can be read and observed by other Australians. On a future occasion I shall have to return to the short remaining explanation of that account.
